page.title: List of Southern Hemisphere tornadoes and tornado outbreaks

revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=June 2011}} ''Parent article:'' '''[[List of tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]]'''
These are some notable [[tornado]]es, [[tornado outbreak]]s, and [[tornado outbreak sequence]]s that have occurred in the Southern Hemisphere including Oceania, and, for the purposes of this list, all of South America and Africa.
== Africa == {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- !Event !Date !Area !Tornadoes !Casualties !Notes |- | Roodepoort, South Africa || 26 November 1948 || [[Highveld]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || 4 fatalities, 100 injuries || 700 homes wrecked, damages estimated at R150 million. Track of 64 km and touching down 15 times.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.itnsource.com/shotlist//BHC_RTV/1948/12/06/BGU411090050/ |title=South African mining town is devastated by cyclone |last= |first= |date= |work= |access-date= |via= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303212400/http://www.itnsource.com/shotlist//ITN/1997/06/26/BSP260697015/ |archivedate=2016-03-03 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://newcastleadvertiser.co.za/39940/top-5-worst-tornadoes-south-african-history/|title=Top 5 worst tornadoes in South African history|website=Newcastleadvertiser.co.za|access-date=2017-02-28}}</ref> |- | Zastron tornado || 26 November 1948 || [[Free State (province)|Free State]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || - || {{Citation needed|date=August 2014}} |- | Albertynesville, South Africa tornado || 30 November 1952 || [[South Africa]] || - || 20 fatalities, 400 injuries || {{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} |- | Paynesville, South Africa tornado || 2 December 1952 || [[South Africa]] || - || 11 fatalities || {{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} |- | Trompsburg, South Africa tornado || 5 November 1976 || [[Karoo]], [[South Africa]] || - || 5+ fatalities || Longest path ever measured in SA, 175 km, mostly through desert{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} |- | Senekal, South Africa tornado || 15 September 1988 || [[South Africa]] || - || 2 fatalities || F3 according to Weather Service. Long track event{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} |- | Welkom, South Africa tornado || 20 March 1990 || [[Free State (South African province)|Free State]], [[South Africa]] || - || destroying 4000 homes || Multi-vortex tornado races through the suburbs of Welkom with a 240 km long severe storm front and a width of up to 1.7 km. Proved to be the most devastating (in monetary terms) in South Africa's history.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} |- | Harrismith tornado || 15 November 1998 || [[Free State (province)|Free State]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || 0 fatalities, 14 injuries || F2 according to Weather Service. Several houses and three airplane hangars were damaged or destroyed.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The tornadic thunderstorm events during the 1998-1999 South African summer|last=de Coning|first=E|author2=Adam, BF |journal=Weather Forecasting Research Programme|date=3 July 2000|page=366|url=http://www.wrc.org.za/Knowledge%20Hub%20Documents/Water%20SA%20Journals/Manuscripts/2000/03/WaterSA_2000_03_1263.pdf|accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref> |- | Mthatha, South Africa tornado<ref name="autogenerated2000">[https://web.archive.org/web/20061126193217/http://www.wrc.org.za/archives/watersa%20archive/2000/July/1263.pdf ]</ref> || 15 December 1998 || [[South Africa]] || - || 15 fatalities, 100 injuries || Tornado tracked through major urban area |- | Umtata tornado || 11 January 1999 || [[Eastern Cape]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || 11 fatalities, 150 injuries || Category unknown. Large amounts of damage was caused including damage to the hospital. Nelson Mandela, previous president of South Africa was in a pharmacy when the tornado hit, and was protected by his bodyguards while lying on the floor. The pharmacy was also damaged, but Mandela was not injured.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tornadoes of Africa|url=http://www.islandnet.com/~see/weather/storm/tornadoes-africa.htm|work=For Strong Winds|publisher=For Strong Winds|accessdate=9 October 2013|date=October 2013}}</ref> |- | Mount Ayliff, South Africa tornado<ref name="autogenerated2000"/> || 18 January 1999 || [[South Africa]] || - || 25 fatalities, 500 injuries || 120 km long track F4 |- | Heidelberg, South Africa tornado<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20010303162902/http://www.nwas.org/ej/heidelberg/index.html ]</ref> || 21 October 1999 || [[South Africa]] || - || 20 injuries || 100+ km path narrowly missed Johannesburg<ref name="de Coning">{{cite web|last=de Coning|first=E|author2=Adam B F|author3=Goliger A M|author4=van Wyk T|title=An F3 tornado in Heidelerg, South Africa|url=http://www.nwas.org/ej/heidelberg|work=National Weather Association|publisher=Weather Forecasting Research Group|accessdate=9 October 2013|date=October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029214257/http://www.nwas.org/ej/heidelberg/|archivedate=29 October 2013|df=}}</ref> |- | Centurion tornado || 21 October 1999 || [[Gauteng]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || unknown fatality, unknown injuries || F1 according to Weather Service. Damage was caused.<ref name="de Coning"/> |- | Mpumalanga, South Africa tornado outbreak || 9 September 2002 || [[Mpumalanga]], [[South Africa]] || 4 || 2 fatalities || Strong line of storms. Some buildings completely flattened{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} |- | Dullstroom tornado || 1 August 2006 || [[Mpumalanga]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || 0 fatalities, 9 injuries || Several homes damaged, roof a high school completely removed. Estimated to be strong F1, possibly F2{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} |- | Vryheid tornado || 20 October 2006 || [[KwaZulu-Natal]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || 0 || Rural huts destroyed on a farm 15 km east of the town. Child almost 'taken up' into tornado. Path estimated to be 4 km long. Estimated F1{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} |- | Klerksdorp tornado || 4 March 2007 || [[North West (South African province)|North West]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || 1 fatality, 3 injuries || F0 (South African Weather Bureah classified it as a "mini tornado"). 200 houses and other buildings damaged.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tornado rips through Klerksdorp Suburbs|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/tornado-rips-through-klerksdorp-suburbs-1.317627#.UlTwSxCapOw|work=IOL News|publisher=IOL News|accessdate=9 October 2013|date=October 2013}}</ref> |- | Molweni tornado || 14 November 2008 || [[KwaZulu-Natal]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || 8 fatalities, 200 injuries || Crossed an urban area. Cars rolled some distance and shipping containers hurled through the air over 200m. Mud huts completely scoured away. Brick houses levelled. Path estimated to be 10 km long. Estimated EF3-4{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} |- | Bulwer tornado || 6 November 2009 || [[KwaZulu-Natal]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || 1 fatality, 30 injuries || F3 according to Weather Service. Cars thrown and cinder brick homes flattened{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} |- | Ficksburg tornado || 3 October 2011 || [[Free State (province)|Free State]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || 1 fatality, 42 injuries || F2 according to Weather Service. 122 houses and shacks destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ficksburg tornado: Red Cross steps in|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Ficksburg-tornado-Red-Cross-steps-in-20111003|work=News24|publisher=News24|accessdate=9 October 2013|date=October 2013}}</ref> |- | Duduza tornado || 3 October 2011 || [[Gauteng]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || 1 fatality, 166 injuries || F2 according to Weather Service. 150 houses destroyed<ref>{{cite web|title=Deadly tornadoes wreak havoc in Duduza, Ficksburg|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2011-10-03-deadly-tornado-strikes-wreak-havoc-in-duduza-ficksburg|work=Mail&Guardian|publisher=Mail&Guardian|accessdate=9 October 2013|date=October 2013}}</ref> |- | Bronkhorstspruit tornado || 13 November 2011 || [[Mpumalanga]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || 0 fatalities, 0 injuries || Category unknown. Minimal damage due touching down in open fields.<ref>{{cite web|title=Severe weather observation: Gauting/Mpumalanga 13 November 2011|url=http://saweatherobserver.blogspot.com/2011/11/severe-weather-observation.html|work=SAWDOS|publisher=SAWDOS|accessdate=9 October 2013|date=October 2013}}</ref> |- | Bethlehem tornado || 23 June 2012 || [[Free State (province)|Free State]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || 8 fatalities, 27 injuries || F2. Several houses was destroyed in Bethlehem and Kestell areas<ref>{{cite web|title=South Africa Tornado Damages Homes, Kills Eight|url=http://www.accuweather.com/en/weather-news/south-africa-tornado-damages-h/66978|work=AccuWeather.com|publisher=Accuweather.com|accessdate=9 October 2013|date=October 2013}}</ref> |- | Deneysville tornado || 23 June 2012 || [[Free State (province)|Free State]], [[South Africa]] || 1 ||1 fatality, 5 injuries|| a lot of damage to waterfront property.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nsri.org.za/2012/06/tornado-rips-through-deneysville/ |title=Tornado rips through Deneysville |publisher=[[National Sea Rescue Institute]] |date=23 June 2012}}</ref> |- | Queenstown – Mthaha tornado || 19 September 2013 || [[Eastern Cape]], [[South Africa]] || 1 ||-|| {{Citation needed|date=August 2014}} |- | Tembisa || 26 July 2016 || [[Gauteng]], [[South Africa]] || 1 || 0 fatalities, 3 injuries || Damaged roof of Phumulani Mall, causing injuries; also damaged roof of nearby hospital.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.enca.com/south-africa/roof-collapse-at-tembisas-phumulani-mall |title=Tornado damages Tembisa Hospital, Phumulani Mall |publisher=[[ENCA|eNews Channel Africa]] |date=26 July 2016}}</ref> |- |Mpumalanga, Standerton |10 December
2016 |Mpumalanga, Standerton, South Africa |1 |0 fatalities |Spotted about 12km outside Standerton on the R23 Volksrust Road<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://citizen.co.za/news/south-africa/1371819/tornado-and-funnel-cloud-appear-near-standerton/|title=Tornado and funnel cloud appear near Standerton|last=reporter|first=CNS|work=The Citizen|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://standertonadvertiser.co.za/46800/videos-tornado-and-funnel-cloud-appears-near-standerton/?repeat=w3tc|title=Videos - Tornado and funnel cloud appear near Standerton {{!}} Standerton Advertiser|date=2016-12-12|work=Standerton Advertiser|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> |- |Mpumalanga Standerton |11 December2016 |Mpumalanga, Standerton, South Africa |1 |0 fatalities |Seen in the Kaalspruit/Bloukop Area<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://standertonadvertiser.co.za/64605/nuusflits-tornado-tussen-standerton-en-amersfoort-vasgevang/?repeat=w3tc|title=’n Video-opname asook foto’s van ’n tornado en die skade wat dit verrig het in die Standerton gebied en omliggende dorpe doen tans die ronde op sosiale media.|date=2017-12-11|work=Standerton Advertiser|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> |- |Vaal Marina |11 December 2016 |Gauteng, South Africa |1 |0 fatalities, +-50 injuries |At least 300 people were displaced and 50 others injured<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://citizen.co.za/news/south-africa/1756010/at-least-50-people-injured-as-tornado-hits-vaal-marina/|title=At least 50 people injured as Tornado hits Vaal Marina|last=reporter|first=ANA and Citizen|work=The Citizen|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en}}</ref> |}
== Oceania ==
=== Australia === {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- !Tornado event !Date !Area !Tornadoes !Casualties !Notes ![[Fujita Scale]] |- | [[EF2 Sydney tornado|1795 Sydney tornado]] || 1795 || Sydney || 1 || 0 || The earliest tornado record in the Bureau of Meteorology archives, it destroyed crops and trees in the early settlement.<ref>{{cite web|last=Evershed |first=Nick |url=http://www.thecourier.com.au/story/1389432/multimedia-tornadoes-in-australia/interactive/ |title=MULTIMEDIA: Tornadoes in Australia |publisher=The Courier |date=2013-03-26 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | Port Phillip tornado || 29 January 1837 || Central [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]] || 1 || 0 || Believed to be the first tornado observed by the colonists of Port Phillip and one of the first observed in Australia. Following a trail of over 60 miles from the heads of Port Phillip to [[Geelong]] and as far north as [[Mount Macedon, Victoria|Mount Macedon]] it caused much damage and uprooting of trees.<ref>pg. 4. The Australian Sydney (extract from the Port Phillip Patriot) 23 March 1839</ref> | |- | Parramatta tornado || 21 December 1841 || [[Parramatta]], [[New South Wales]] || 1 || 0 || Tornado observed west of Sydney causing damage to churches and schools in Parramatta, destroying homes and uprooting trees.<ref>pg. 6. The Sydney Herald. 10 January 1842</ref> | |- | Murrumbidgee tornado || 9 October 1844 || [[Murrumbidgee District]], [[New South Wales]] || 1 || 0 || Part of a larger storm cell which caused extensive flooding, a tornado was observed in Murrumbidgee District near [[Gundagai]] causing extensive damage to forest area.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article12424458 |title=News from the interior |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |location=NSW |date=10 October 1844 |accessdate=9 June 2013 |page=4 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> | |- | Devil's river tornado || 26 December 1848 || Devil's River, [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]] || 1 || 0 fatalities, 3 injured || Tornado swept across farmland hurling large hailstones, killing numerous livestock and injuring settlers.<ref>pg. 2. The Sydney Morning Herald. 10 January 1849</ref> | |- | Wee Waa tornado || 26 November 1849 || [[Wee Waa]], [[New South Wales]] || 1 || 0|| Huts were unroofed and trees uprooted.<ref>pg. 2. The Maitland Mercury & Hunter River General Advertiser Wednesday 19 December 1849</ref> | |- | Campbell's river tornado ||5 January 1852 || [[Campbell's River, New South Wales]] || 1 || 0|| Destructive tornado cut a path through farmland and forest, reaching the outskirts of [[Bathurst, New South Wales]].<ref name="pg. 3. Empire. 12 April 1852">pg. 3. Empire. 12 April 1852</ref><ref>pg. 4. The Maitland Mercury & Hunter River General Advertiser. Wednesday 14 January 1852</ref> | |- | Waratah tornado || 16 September 1860 || [[Newcastle, New South Wales|Newcastle region]] || 1 || 0|| Related to storm over Newcastle, a tornado cut a path from [[Minmi, New South Wales|Minmi]] to [[Hexham, New South Wales|Hexham]] and Waratah, throwing wagons through the air and uprooting trees on its way toward the ocean.<ref name="pg. 3. Empire. 12 April 1852"/><ref>pg. 5. The Sydney Morning Herald. Tuesday 18 September 1860</ref> | |- | Chetwynd tornado || 1 July 1861 || Western Victoria || 1 || 1|| Large tornado reported at Chetwynd Station moving along the tributary of the [[Glenelg River (Victoria)|Glenelg River]] toward Harrow carried large objects including trees, poles and huts distances from several yards to miles through the air.<ref>"THE TORNADO AT CHETWYND STATION" ON JULY 1, 1861. Bell's Life in Sydney and Sporting Chronicle. 15 February 1862</ref> Two men were reported to have been thrown great distances in the air, with one returning to the ground dead.<ref>Glenelg River in History. pg.8. The Argus 19 April 1924</ref> | |- | Hamilton tornado || 22 October 1861 || Western Victoria || 1 || 0 || Originating near the South Australian border at [[Lindsay, Victoria|Lindsay]] and passing through [[Casterton, Victoria|Casterton]], a tornado cut a path through [[Hamilton, Victoria|Hamilton]] where it caused extensive damage to buildings before moving east uprooting trees and taking the roofs off houses. Scotch church in Hamilton was destroyed, along with another church and several commercial premises including two hotels were leveled causing [[A£]]5000 in damage through no casualties were reported.<ref>pg. 1. The Star. 26 October 1861</ref><ref>pg. 4. Border Watch. Friday 8 November 1861</ref> | |- | Maryborough tornado || 25 February 1864 || North-west Victoria || 1 || 2 || Tornado cut a swathe from [[Maryborough, Victoria|Maryborough]] to [[Creswick, Victoria|Creswick]] and [[Bullarook]] north of [[Ballarat]]. A father and son were killed by a tree thrown through the air and numerous others were injured. The tornado damaged numerous buildings and uprooting trees.<ref>pg. 4. The Argus Thursday 25 February 1864</ref> | |- | Beechworth tornado || 26 October 1865 || Beechworth Victoria || 1 || 1 fatality, numerous injuries || Massive damaged to Beechworth from tornado leaving churches, schools demolished, houses unroofed and objects thrown great distances and a Chinese man died inside a collapsed hut.<ref>TORNADO AT BEECEWORTH. OVENS ADVERTISER, OCT. 28, 1865</ref> | |- | Bowen tornado || 22 February 1876 || Bowen, Queensland || 1 || 1 fatality, numerous injuries || Destructive tornado caused severe damage to [[Bowen, Queensland|Bowen]]. One killed, many more injured, some seriously. Damages amounting to at least [[A£]]7,000, many buildings were badly damaged or destroyed including the Bowen hospital, where many patients sustained minor injuries.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article18341002 |title=General News. |newspaper=[[The Queenslander]] |location=Brisbane |date=26 February 1876 |accessdate=9 June 2013 |page=26 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> | |- | Nhill tornado || 19 November 1897 || [[Wimmera]] region, north western [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]] || 1 || 3 || Deadly tornado leaving a destructive trail across over 250 km of north western Victoria virtually destroyed the town of [[Nhill, Victoria|Nhill]] where [[A£]]50,000 of damage was done including all of the town's churches and many of the houses. Extensive damage was also inflicted on the town of [[Donald, Victoria|Donald]] where one person died and a church, school and numerous other buildings were demolished at a total damage bill of [[A£]]4,000. At [[Maryborough, Victoria|Maryborough]] a further 2 deaths were recorded. At [[Rupanyup, Victoria|Rupanyup]] the damage was estimated at [[A£]]200.<ref>Pg. 5 The Advertiser. 23 November 1897</ref><ref>Pg 2. Queanbeyan Age Wednesday 24 November 1897</ref><ref>THE TORNADO AT NHILL, DESCRIPTION BY AN EYEWITNESS. North Otago Times, Volume XXXVI, Issue 9079, 13 December 1897, Page 4</ref> | |- | Nevertire tornado || 29 December 1897 || [[New South Wales]] || 1 || 0 || Destructive tornado with a path 14 miles long struck the town of [[Nevertire, New South Wales]] leaving many people injured.<ref>"Tornado at Nevertire". pg. 7. Launceston Examiner. 1 January 1897</ref> | |- | Narrabri tornado || 2 December 1900 || [[New South Wales]] || 1 || 0 || Destructive tornado causing total estimated damage of [[A£]]8,000.<ref>pg 2. Barrier Miner. 6 December 1900</ref> | |- | Narrabri tornado || 6 January 1902 || [[New South Wales]] || 1 || 1 fatality, numerous injured || Second, more destructive tornado at Narrabri destroyed the railway goods shed. Few buildings were undamaged leaving an estimated total damage of [[A£]]10,000.<ref>"Destructive Tornado at Narrabri. Houses Levelled to the Ground". pg 3. Clarence and Richmond Examiner. 7 January 1902</ref> | |- | Ballarat tornado || 19 August 1909 || [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] || 1 || 1 fatality, >7 injured || During a severe flooding event, a tornado touched down in [[Ballarat]] sweeping across the city's northern and eastern suburbs destroying numerous homes in [[Ballarat North, Victoria|Ballarat North]], [[Soldiers Hill, Victoria|Soldiers Hill]], [[Black Hill, Victoria|Black Hill]] and [[Ballarat East, Victoria|Ballarat East]]. The tornado lifted before again touching down at [[Eureka, Victoria|Eureka]] where it destroyed more homes before dissipating.<ref>"The Ballarat Tornado" p6. The Mercury. 25 August 1909</ref><ref>"Furious Storm at Ballarat – several houses demolished, woman crushed to death, several persons injured" p5. The West Australian. 23 August 1909</ref> | |- | [[Marong, Victoria|Marong]] tornado || 27 September 1911 || [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] || 1 || 1 fatality, >12 injured || Likely an F3, it caused severe damage to [[Marong, Victoria|Marong]] and [[Lockwood, Victoria|Lockwood]]. First tornado photographed in Australia.<ref name="australiangeographic.com.au">{{cite web|url=http://www.australiangeographic.com.au/journal/on-this-day-in-history-first-picture-of-a-tornado-in-australia.htm |title=On this day in history: first picture of a tornado in Australia |publisher=Australian Geographic |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | [[Brighton tornado]] || 2 February 1918 || [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] || 3 || >2 fatalities ||Known as the 'Brighton Cyclone',<ref>{{cite web|title=The Brighton Cyclone 2nd February 1918 |publisher=Brighton Historical Society Inc |url=http://home.vicnet.net.au/~vbhs/Articles/128_Brighton_Cyclone.htm |accessdate=2008-06-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080809021440/http://home.vicnet.net.au/~vbhs/Articles/128_Brighton_Cyclone.htm |archivedate=2008-08-09 |df= }}</ref> these tornadoes hit the suburb of [[Brighton, Victoria|Brighton]], a suburb of [[Melbourne]]. At one location two tornado tracks crossed, creating (in the language of the day) a "veritable orgy of destruction".<ref name="storm1">{{cite web | title = Tornadoes | work = Commonwealth of Australia | publisher = Bureau of Meteorology | url = http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/c20thc/storm1.shtml | accessdate = 2008-06-09|archiveurl=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/96122/20090317-1643/www.bom.gov.au/lam/climate/levelthree/c20thc/storm1.html|archivedate=17 March 2009}}</ref> In the few minutes that the storm lasted, two people were killed and many others injured. Wind speeds were estimated at 320 km/h (Fujita rating F3), making this possibly the most intense tornado to hit a major Australian city.<ref>{{cite web | title = Major historic severe weather | work = Commonwealth of Australia | publisher = Geoscience Australia | url = http://www.ga.gov.au/hazards/severeweather/historic.jsp | accessdate = 2008-06-09}}</ref> Total estimated damage was [[A£]]100,000 – 150,000. | |- | Portarlington tornado || 9 January 1921 || [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] || 2 || 0 fatalities, >1 injuries || A tornado and a waterspout formed in the area of [[Corio Bay]] moving east where it struck [[Portarlington, Victoria|Portarlington]] and [[St Leonards, Victoria|St Leonards]] before dissipating in [[Port Phillip]]. The Grand Hotel was damaged and the roofs removed from a church and several houses. Trees were torn out of the ground. Reports of several people being carried up to 40 feet through the air.<ref>"Tornado at Portarlington" p4. The Argus. 10 January 1921</ref><ref>"Waterspout at Corio Bay" p3. Geraldton Guardian. 13 January 1921</ref> | |- | Geelong tornado || 22 July 1926 || [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] || 1 || 1 fatality, 20-30 injured || Tornado that originated in the [[Western District (Victoria)|Western District]] moved east, striking [[Lismore, Victoria|Lismore]] in South West of [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]] where there was considerable damage and trees torn out of the ground. Headed east, the tornado cut a swathe through the south west of Victoria until it reached the populated area of [[Geelong]]. It cut a path through the southern suburbs of [[Highton, Victoria|Highton]], [[Marshall, Victoria|Marshall]] and [[Belmont, Victoria|Belmont]] where a total of seven homes were destroyed, most in Belmont. The tornado continued to cross [[Port Phillip]] where it continued gathering pace. It made final [[Landfall (meteorology)|landfall]] at [[Brighton, Victoria|Brighton]] where it destroyed two churches, two halls and several other buildings.<ref>pg 5. Examiner 23 July 1926</ref> Total estimated damage in Geelong was [[A£]]40,000.<ref>"Geelong Tornado. Relief Committee at Work" pg 12. The Argus. 27 July 1926</ref> | |- | [[Dwellingup]] tornado || 16 April 1954 || [[Western Australia]] || 1 || 0 fatalities || Rated F3, through [[jarrah]] forest along an {{convert|10|km|mi|abbr=on}} path, and up to {{convert|200|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide near Lyalls Mill.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inflowimages.com/TornadoesInWa/HistoryWA.htm |title=Home |publisher=Inflowimages.com |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | Port Macquarie tornado || 6 July 1962 || New South Wales || 1 || 3 fatalities || An intense waterspout reached landfall at [[Port Macquarie]] causing widespread damage. 3 men were killed as a house collapsed.<ref>{{cite web|author=Nov. 19, 2013, 10:33 a.m. |url=http://www.portnews.com.au/story/1917568/remembering-the-62-tornado-which-killed-three/?cs=257 |title=Remembering the '62 tornado which killed three | Port Macquarie News |publisher=Portnews.com.au |date=2013-11-19 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | [[Busselton]] tornado || 10 July 1964 || Western Australia || 1 || 1 fatality || 1 person was killed when his car was pulled off the road by a tornado near Busselton.<ref name="Inflow Images">{{cite web | title = A Complete History of Tornadoes in WA | publisher = Inflow Images | url = http://www.inflowimages.com/TornadoesInWa/HistoryWA.htm | accessdate = 2008-06-09}}</ref> | |- | [[Bulahdelah tornado]] || 1 January 1970 || [[New South Wales]] || 1 || 0 fatalities || Believed to be one of the strongest Australian tornadoes, believed to be at least F4 possibly F5.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} Left a damage path {{convert|21|km|mi|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|1|-|1.6|km|mi|abbr=on}} wide through the Bulahdelah State Forest. According to reports, it threw a two-ton tractor {{convert|100|m|ft|abbr=on}} through the air, depositing it upside down. It is estimated that the tornado destroyed over one million trees.<ref name="islandnet.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.islandnet.com/~see/weather/storm/tornadoes-aunzea.htm |title=For Strong Winds: Tornadoes of Australia and New Zealand |publisher=Islandnet.com |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | [[Kin Kin]] tornado || 14 August 1971 || Queensland || 1 || 3 fatalities || Three people killed at Kin Kin (a small community between Gympie and Noosa). This is the deadliest tornado recorded in Australia to date.<ref name="storm1"/> | |- | [[Brisbane]] tornado || 4 November 1973 || [[Queensland]] || 1, other funnels reported || 0 fatalities || Perhaps most destructive Australian tornado. It had a path length of {{convert|51|km|mi|abbr=on}}, and peak wind-speeds are estimated to be in excess of {{convert|300|kph|mph|abbr=on}}. 500 houses were unrooved, 1,400 destroyed and 500 declared 'structurally unsafe'. At least one home was swept away from its foundation. Rated F3.<ref name="storm1"/><ref>{{cite web|title=EMA Disasters Database |work=Commonwealth of Australia |publisher=Emergency Management Australia |url=http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/c85916e930b93d50ca256d050020cb1f/fe6e777cef08c479ca256d3300057bae?OpenDocument |accessdate=2008-06-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080817183923/http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/c85916e930b93d50ca256d050020cb1f/fe6e777cef08c479ca256d3300057bae?OpenDocument |archivedate=2008-08-17 |df= }}</ref> | |- | [[Port Hedland]] tornado || 17 December 1975 || Western Australia || 1 || 0 fatalities ||A spectacular tornado with a purple funnel was on the ground right in front of the weather bureau.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inflowimages.com/TornadoesInWa/TornadosInWa.htm |title=Home |publisher=Inflowimages.com |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | [[Sandon tornado]] || 13 November 1976 || Victoria || 3 || 2 fatalities ||Strong F2 or an F3. Fatalities occurred when a car was thrown by the tornado with occupants inside. This tornado from the outbreak caused $300,000 in damage.<ref>{{cite web | title = Sandon Tornado VIC | publisher = Inflow Images | url = http://www.inflowimages.com/AustralianTornadicEvents/sandon.html | accessdate = 2008-06-09}}</ref> | |- | [[Northam, Western Australia|Northam]] tornado || 21 December 1977 || Western Australia || 1 || 0 fatalities || Described as a most beautiful Australian tornado due to the colour of the vortex being red from picking up the red-coloured dirt. Path length 6–7 km and it uprooted several large gum trees.<ref>{{cite web | title = The Northam Tornado | publisher = Inflow Images | url = http://www.inflowimages.com/TornadoesInWa/northam/northam.html | accessdate = 2008-06-09}}</ref> | |- |[[Drummoyne, New South Wales|Drummoyne]] and [[Hunters Hill, New South Wales|Hunters Hill]] tornado |10 February 1978 |New South Wales |1 |0 fatalities |During an outbreak of severe thunderstorms in eastern New South Wales affecting Newcastle Sydney and Wollongong, a storm produced a tornado in the Drummoyne and Hunters Hill area of metropolitan Sydney, ripping the roof from a house.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/nsw/sevwx/7079summ.shtml|title=Bureau - Severe Storm Events - 1970/1979|website=Bom.gov.au|access-date=2016-03-09}}</ref> The severe weather injured a total of eight across the affected area, causing an estimated A$15 million in damage with a 2011 normalized cost of A$215 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.emknowledge.gov.au/resource/48/1978/severe-storm---newcastle-sydney-wollongong-1978|title=Severe Storm - Newcastle, Sydney, Wollongong 1978|last=http://distriqt.com|first=distriqt //|website=Australian Emergency Management Knowledge Hub|access-date=2016-03-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160309090850/https://www.emknowledge.gov.au/resource/48/1978/severe-storm---newcastle-sydney-wollongong-1978|archive-date=2016-03-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> | |- | Port Macquarie Tornado || 13 September 1985 || New South Wales || 1 || – || Buildings were destroyed and cars thrown through the air causing a total of more than $3 million in damages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Nov. 20, 2013, 8 a.m. |url=http://www.portnews.com.au/story/1919136/the-great-twister-of-1985/?cs=257 |title=The great twister of 1985 | Port Macquarie News |publisher=Portnews.com.au |date=2013-11-20 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | Elsmore tornadoes || 6 November 1989 || [[Elsmore, New South Wales]] || 3 || - || Destructive tornado categorised F3 by the Bureau of Meteorology damaged up to 25 homes, including 5 which were completely destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ingall |first=Jennifer |url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2013/11/26/3899398.htm |title=Tornadoes not so uncommon - ABC New England North West NSW - Australian Broadcasting Corporation |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=2013-11-27 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | SE QLD tornadoes || 24 December 1989 || South East Queensland|| >1 || - || A massive supercell (with cloud tops as high as {{convert|77,000|ft|km|abbr=on}}) tore through Brisbane and parts of SE QLD, producing several tornadoes along its path. A combination of straight line winds and a tornado unrooved 500 houses, damaged 1000 and left 12 structurally unsafe in the city of Redcliffe (approximately {{convert|25|km|mi|abbr=on}} north of Brisbane).<ref>{{cite web|author=Ben Quinn |url=http://www.bsch.au.com/reports/24_12_89.shtml |title=BSCH - Recent Events - Christmas Eve 1989 Tornadic Supercell |publisher=Bsch.au.com |date=1989-12-24 |accessdate=2014-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130827123350/http://www.bsch.au.com/reports/24_12_89.shtml |archivedate=2013-08-27 |df= }}</ref> | |- | Chisholm Tornado || 1990 || Australian Capital Territory || 1 || 5 || Tornado hit [[Canberra]] suburb of [[Chisholm, Australian Capital Territory|Chisholm]] in 1990 destroying a wooden church and damaging 37 houses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.disasters.ema.gov.au/Browse%20Details/DisasterEventDetails.aspx?DisasterEventID=1203 |title=Event – Chisholm, ACT: Tornado |work=EMA Disasters Database |publisher=Australian Government: Emergency Management Australia |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316152806/http://www.disasters.ema.gov.au/Browse%20Details/DisasterEventDetails.aspx?DisasterEventID=1203 |archivedate=2012-03-16 |df= }}</ref> | |- | [[1992 Queensland storms|SE QLD tornadoes]] || 29 November 1992 || Queensland, || 2 || 0 fatalities || The tornado at Bucca (west of [[Bundaberg, Queensland]]) is the most intense Australian tornado, rated F4 officially. Hail the size of cricket balls accompanied the storm.<ref name="storm1"/> A tornado also struck Oakhurst rated F3. | |- | Tucabia tornado || 1 November 1993 || New South Wales || 1 || 0 fatalities || Rated F2 with 200m base, accompanied by golf ball sized hail and lasted for 20 minutes. 8 houses totally destroyed, 35 others damaged. 2 people injured.<ref>{{cite web | title = Tucabia Tornado: Saturday 20th November 1993 | publisher = Australian Severe Weather | url = http://australiasevereweather.com/storm_news/1997/docs/9711-04.htm | accessdate = 2008-06-09}}</ref> | |- | Blue Mountains tornado || 20 November 1994 || New South Wales || 1 || 0 || Worst hit Yellow Rock in the Blue Mountains. Destruction to multiple houses, trees up-rooted. F0/F1 <ref name="bom.gov.au">{{cite web|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/nsw/sevwx/9000summ.shtml|title=Bureau - Severe Storm Events - 1990/2000|author=|date=|work=bom.gov.au|accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref> | |- | Chatswood tornado || 20 November 1994 || New South Wales || 1 || 0 || Chatswood, north of Sydney. Destruction to multiple houses, trees up-rooted. F0/F1 <ref name="bom.gov.au"/> | |- | [[Merimbula]] tornado || 16 April 1995 || New South Wales || 2 || 0 fatalities, 34 injuries || An F2 tornado ripped through the centre of the town of Merimbula in SE New South Wales. 34 people were injured, approximately 200 buildings were damaged, 12 were destroyed. Two funnels were reported in the storm, which also caused damage at nearby Pambula.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/b3212955d6fc1e73ca256d3300057c10?OpenDocument |title= Merimbula – Pambula, NSW: Tornado |accessdate=March 11, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080916091501/http://www.ema.gov.au/ema/emadisasters.nsf/54273a46a9c753b3ca256d0900180220/b3212955d6fc1e73ca256d3300057c10?OpenDocument |archivedate=September 16, 2008 }}</ref> | |- | New South Wales tornado outbreak || 29 September 1996 || Central New South Wales || 3 confirmed || 0, fatalities || The largest outbreak of severe thunderstorms ever documented in NSW occurs. Three tornadoes, hail up to 7 cm and wind gusts to 156 km/h are reported. Over $92 million insured loss from hail and wind is sustained at Armidale, NSW. Total estimated cost for the region is $340 million.<ref>{{cite web | title = Severe Thunderstorms | work = Commonwealth of Australia | publisher = Bureau of Meteorology | url = http://www.bom.gov.au/info/thunder/#storms | accessdate = 2008-06-09}}</ref> 3 tornadoes confirmed at Bundella, Gilgandra and Elong Elong.<ref>{{cite web | title = Significant Weather - September 1996 | work = Commonwealth of Australia | publisher = Bureau of Meteorology | url = http://www.bom.gov.au/inside/services_policy/public/sigwxsum/sigw0996.shtml#thunder | accessdate = 2008-06-09}}</ref> | |- | [[Perth]] tornado || 15 July 1996 || Western Australia || 1 || 0, fatalities<br/>5, injured ||Short lived tornado associated with a cold front. This was indicated by the tornado's speed which was estimated to have been {{convert|80|kph|mph|abbr=on}} and path approximately {{convert|4|km|mi|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|40|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide, which lasted on the ground for approximately 3 minutes.<ref>{{cite web | title = EMA Disasters Database | work = Commonwealth of Australia | publisher = Emergency Management Australia | url = http://www.disasters.ema.gov.au/Browse%20Details/DisasterEventDetails.aspx?DisasterEventID=491 | accessdate = 2012-04-15 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> | |- | [[Fremantle, Western Australia|Fremantle]] tornado || 25 August 1999 || Western Australia || 1 || 0 || A tornado went through Fremantle, south of Perth, leaving a {{convert|100|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide {{convert|8|-|9|km|mi|abbr=on}} long track. Several people were trapped in an apartment block when the tornado caused the roof to collapse.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/weather/wa/sevwx/25august1999.shtml|archiveurl=http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/55863/20090310-1802/www.bom.gov.au/weather/wa/sevwx/25august1999.html|archivedate=10 March 2009|title=Severe Thunderstorms in WA, Australia, 25 August 1999|publisher=[[Bureau of Meteorology]]|accessdate=25 December 2012}}</ref> | |- | [[Greystanes]] tornado || 3 November 2000 || New South Wales || 3 Confirmed || 0 fatalities || A tornadic thunderstorm moved through the Sydney Metropolitan Area over the afternoon/early evening. Three F0/F1 tornadoes struck several suburbs including [[Constitution Hill, New South Wales|Constitution Hill]], [[Wentworthville]], [[Pendle Hill, New South Wales|Pendle Hill]] and [[Greystanes]]. Golf ball sized hail, the widespread downing of trees and overhead powerlines were observed during the damage survey as was minor to moderate damage to structure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/nsw/sevwx/tornadofact.shtml/|title=Facts on Tornadoes in NSW |accessdate=February 4, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110327104637/http://www.bom.gov.au/nsw/sevwx/tornadofact.shtml |archivedate=March 27, 2011 }}</ref> | |- | [[Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race waterspout|South coast tornado]] || 26 December 2001 || Off the south coast of New South Wales, Australia || 1 || 0 fatalities || During the [[Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race]], the boat ''Nicorette'' recorded wind speeds of close to {{convert|100|kn|mph|abbr=on}} and was struck by hail the size of golf balls. According to the boat's meteorologist, the tornado began with a diameter of around {{convert|50|m|ft|abbr=on}}, but grew in size until it was {{convert|500|m|ft|abbr=on}} across.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.cnn.com/2001/WORLD/sailing/12/27/sydney.spt/index.html |work=CNN |title='Twister' horror for Sydney-Hobart yachts |date=December 28, 2001 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080325151824/http://archives.cnn.com/2001/WORLD/sailing/12/27/sydney.spt/index.html |archivedate=March 25, 2008 |df= }}</ref> | |- | [[South Australia]] tornado outbreak || 18 May 2002 || [[South Australia]] || 2 || 0 fatalities || Two tornadoes associated with a strong cold front occurred in the morning. The first tornado, at 6:15 am (ACST), near Coulta, {{convert|7|km|mi|abbr=on}} in length, uprooted several trees and damaged others on farmland. The second, at 10 am (ACST), caused a narrow {{convert|2|km|mi|abbr=on}} long path of damage through the Adelaide suburbs of Rosslyn Park and Wattle Park. In the evening, another tornado or severe downburst associated with a hail storm occurred at Two Wells, causing a damage path of less than {{convert|500|m|ft|abbr=on}} in length.<ref>{{cite web | title = MonthlyClimate Summary - South Australian Regional Office (May 2002) | work = Commonwealth of Australia | publisher = Bureau of Meteorology | url = http://www.bom.gov.au/announcements/media_releases/sa/20020603.shtml | accessdate = 2008-06-09}}</ref> | |- | Niangala tornado || 13 October 2002 || New South Wales || 1 || 0 fatalities || A F2 tornado in Niangala damaged hundreds of trees and destroyed two houses, and, nearby, hail up to {{convert|6|cm|in|abbr=on}} was recorded at Walcha.<ref>{{cite web | title = Summary of Significant Severe Thunderstorm Events in NSW - 2002/03 | work = Commonwealth of Australia | publisher = Bureau of Meteorology | url = http://www.bom.gov.au/weather/nsw/sevwx/0203summ.shtml | accessdate = 2008-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Facts on Tornadoes in NSW | work = Commonwealth of Australia | publisher = Bureau of Meteorology | url = http://www.bom.gov.au/weather/nsw/sevwx/tornadofact.shtml | accessdate = 2008-06-09}}</ref> | |- | [[2003 Bendigo tornado|Bendigo]] tornado || 18 May 2003 || Victoria || 1 || 0 fatalities || A tornado caused considerable damage within the City of Bendigo, Victoria, damaging around 50 homes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bendigo Tornado |publisher=Australian Sky & Weather |url=http://www.stormchasers.au.com/18_05_03.htm |accessdate=2008-06-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612040303/http://www.stormchasers.au.com/18_05_03.htm |archivedate=2008-06-12 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Baker | first = Richard |author2=Rood, David | title = 'It was a dead-set tornado all right' | work = Fairfax | publisher = The Age | date = 2003-05-20 | url = http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/05/19/1053196525072.html | accessdate = 2008-06-09 | location=Melbourne}}</ref> | |- | [[Grampians National Park|Grampians]] tornado || 4 January 2004 || Victoria || 1 || 0 fatalities || A tornado caused considerable damage along a wide track within the Grampains National Park in western Victoria. The tornado track was observed from an aircraft about a week later. The tornado tore large trees out of the ground, leaving a bare patch of about {{convert|8|-|10|ha|abbr=on}} without any vegetation at all.<ref>{{cite web | title = Tornado strikes in Grampians | work = Fairfax | publisher = The Stawell Times-News | date = 2004-01-16 | url = http://stawell.yourguide.com.au/news/local/news/general/tornado-strikes-in-grampians/407162.aspx | accessdate = 2008-06-09 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20120724110935/http://stawell.yourguide.com.au/news/local/news/general/tornado-strikes-in-grampians/407162.aspx | archivedate = 2012-07-24 | df = }}</ref> | |- | [[Noble Park]] tornado || 9 June 2004 || Victoria || 1 || 0 fatalities || An F1 tornado caused considerable damage along a damage path {{convert|3.2|km|mi}} long and from {{convert|50|-|200|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide. More than 70 homes in the Melbourne suburbs of Noble Park and [[Mulgrave, Victoria|Mulgrave]] were affected. Winds were estimated at up to {{convert|180|kph|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/06/10/1086749839466.html?from=storylhs | location=Melbourne | work=The Age | title=Twister's trail leaves households reeling | date=June 11, 2004 | first=Andrew | last=Webster}}</ref> | |- | [[Coonabarabran]] tornado || 20 January 2005 || New South Wales || 1 || 0 fatalities ||This tornado formed at 4:30pm (AEDT) during a severe thunderstorm and ran a path of over {{convert|5|km|mi|abbr=on}} towards the SE crossing the Oxley Highway, where it uprooted many trees adjacent to the highway and scoured the ground. F1 or F2.<ref>{{cite web | title = Tornado near Coonabarabran 2005 Jan 20 | publisher = Siding Spring Survey | url = http://msowww.anu.edu.au/~rmn/tornado.htm | accessdate = 2008-06-09 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080719052258/http://msowww.anu.edu.au/~rmn/tornado.htm | archivedate = 2008-07-19 | df = }}</ref> | |- | [[Broken Hill]] tornado || 6 November 2005 || New South Wales || 1 || 0 fatalities || Damage to 100 homes, total damage bill of {{AUD|3.8}} million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/nsw/sevwx/0506summ.shtml |title=Severe Storm Events - 2005/2006 |publisher=BoM |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | [[La Perouse, New South Wales|La Perouse]] tornado || 4 August 2006 || New South Wales || 1 || 0 fatalities ||A super cellular waterspout/tornado struck the Sydney suburb of La Perouse. It caused damage to several buildings, and brought down powerlines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/inside/services_policy/public/sigwxsum/pdf/sigw0806.pdf |format=PDF |title=SIGNIFICANT WEATHER – August 2006 |website=Bom.gov.au |accessdate=2017-02-28}}</ref> |F1 |- | [[Leschenault, Western Australia|Leschenault]] tornado || 7 August 2006 || Western Australia || 1 || 2 injuries ||This tornado hit an outer suburb of [[Bunbury, Western Australia|Bunbury]] ({{convert|163|km|mi|abbr=on}} south of [[Perth]]) in the early hours of the morning. It damaged sixty houses, with seven of these completely losing their roofs.<ref>{{cite news | last = Welch | first = Dylan | title = Sixty homes hit by tornado | work = Fairfax | publisher = The Age | date = 2003-05-20 | url = http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/sixty-homes-hit-by-tornado/2006/08/07/1154802793438.html | accessdate = 2008-06-09 | location=Melbourne}}</ref> The tornado injured two, produced a damage path 200 meters wide and 2 kilometers long.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/inside/services_policy/public/sigwxsum/pdf/sigw0806.pdf|title=SIGNIFICANT WEATHER – August 2006|last=|first=|date=|website=Bureau of Meteorology|publisher=|access-date=2016-02-27}}</ref> |F2 |- | [[Kakadu National Park|Kakadu]] tornado || 1 March 2007 || [[Northern Territory]] || 1 || 0 fatalities || Severe damage was observed in [[Kakadu National Park]], at the Mary River Ranger Station. Two caravans were destroyed, and many [[Eucalyptus|eucalypts]] and [[Casuarina|ironwoods]] were uprooted. The Bureau of Meteorology experts estimated the wind speeds to be between {{convert|230|-|270|kph|mph|abbr=on}}, making this an F2/F3 tornado.<ref>{{cite web | title = Tornado causes severe damage in Kakadu National Park | work = Commonwealth of Australia | publisher = Bureau of Meteorology | url = http://www.bom.gov.au/announcements/media_releases/nt/20070320.shtml | accessdate = 2008-06-09}}</ref> | |- | [[You Yangs]] landspout || 14 May 2007 || Victoria || 1 || 0 fatalities || A [[landspout]] tornado was sighted near the You Yangs near [[Geelong]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. The tornado lasted for several minutes as it traversed across farmland and had an estimated diameter of {{convert|50|-|100|m|ft|abbr=on}}. No damage was reported.<ref>{{cite web|last=Martin |first=Steve |url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2007/05/15/1923024.htm |title=Pictures of the You Yangs twister – ABC South West Vic – Australian Broadcasting Corporation |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=2007-05-15 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | [[Moana, South Australia|Moana]] tornado || 21 May 2007 || South Australia || 1 || 0 fatalities || Several houses were damaged and trees were blown down or snapped off at Moana due to a tornado.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120321223949/http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/mini-tornado-hits-south/story-e6frea83-1111113581396]</ref> | |- | [[Dunoon, New South Wales|Dunoon]] tornado || 26 October 2007 || New South Wales || 1 || 0 fatalities ||Multi vortex tornado near the town of [[Lismore, New South Wales|Lismore]], caught by storm chaser Jimmy Deguara.<ref>{{cite news | title = Dunoon Tornado – near Lismore, NSW | work = Australia Severe Weather | publisher = Jimmy Deguara | date = 2007-10-27 | url = http://australiasevereweather.com/tornadoes_australia.htm | accessdate = 2008-06-08}}</ref> The tornado blew out the walls of a church, tore the roofs off about 20 residences, and a piece of debris hit a power sub-station that exploded, causing 3000 homes to be without power.<ref>{{cite news | title = Village cops battering as freak twister pays a visit | work=Sydney Morning Herald | date = 2007-10-28 | url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/freak-tornado-hits-nsw/2007/10/27/1192941400158.html | accessdate = 2008-06-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Village cops battering as freak twister pays a visit | work = APN News & Media Ltd | publisher = The Northern Star | url = http://www.northernstar.com.au/?storyid=3753461&thesection=localnews&thesubsection=&thesecondsubsection= | accessdate = 2008-06-08}}</ref> | |- | "Ballarat" tornado || 20 December 2007 || [[Ballarat]] || 1 || 0 || Footage and photographs taken of large but brief tornado taken by storm chasers in rural area north of Ballarat, part of a storm complex that affected Castlemaine. No damage reported.<ref name="australiangeographic.com.au"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stormchasers.au.com/20_12_07.htm |title=Ballarat Tornado, Australia - 20th December 2007 |publisher=Stormchasers.au.com |date=2007-12-20 |accessdate=2014-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223084944/http://www.stormchasers.au.com/20_12_07.htm |archivedate=2015-02-23 |df= }}</ref> | |- | [[Perth]] tornado || 9 June 2008 || Western Australia || 1 || 0 fatalities || Confirmed by the Bureau of Meteorology, the tornado swept through the southern suburbs of Perth just after 7.30 (AWST) in the morning and damaged more than 130 homes. Residents from an Aged Care facility in Cooloongup were evacuated as the roof of an activity room was blown off and the hostel is without power or water.<ref>{{cite web | title = Perth tornado 'may have hit 150km/h' | work = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | publisher = ABC News | date = 2008-06-09 | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/06/09/2269299.htm | accessdate = 2008-06-09}}</ref> | |- | [[Nimmitabel]] tornado || 24 December 2008 || New South Wales || 1 || 0 fatalities || A tornado occurred between Nimmitabel and [[Cooma]], with severe storms that affected the region.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/news/local/news/general/twists-and-turns-on-road-to-canberra/1394600.aspx|title=Twists and turns on road to Canberra |accessdate=June 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926125805/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/news/local/news/general/twists-and-turns-on-road-to-canberra/1394600.aspx |archivedate=September 26, 2009 }}</ref> | |- | [[Atherton, Queensland|Atherton]] tornado || 7 February 2010 || Queensland || 1 || 0 fatalities || A tornado struck a farm just south of the town of Atherton in Queensland, Australia causing damage to corn fields and farm equipment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weatherzone.com.au/news/tornado-tears-through-crops/13887 |title=Weather News – Tornado tears through crops |publisher=Weatherzone.com.au |date=2010-02-17 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | [[Lennox Head]] waterspout/tornado || 3 June 2010 || New South Wales || 2 || 0 fatalities || A major storm and [[waterspout]]/tornado destroyed homes and caused multiple injuries at Lennox Head.<ref>{{cite news|last=Tatnell|first=Paul|title= Waterspout wrecks homes in NSW town as storm hits hard |url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/waterspout-wrecks-homes-in-nsw-town-as-storm-hits-hard-20100603-x0fy.html|accessdate=3 June 2010|newspaper=Sydney Morning Herald|date=3 June 2010}}</ref> Police say a number of homes have been destroyed, powerlines are down and several caravans have been overturned. Paramedics say several people have been injured in the storm but no-one is missing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/local/7337598/waterspout-becomes-tornado-on-nsw-north-coast-reports/|title=No disaster declaration for storm |accessdate=June 2, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605193247/http://au.news.yahoo.com/a/-/local/7337598/waterspout-becomes-tornado-on-nsw-north-coast-reports/ |archivedate=June 5, 2010 }}</ref> | |- | [[Trawalla, Victoria|Trawalla]] tornado || 30 July 2010 || Victoria || 1 || 0 fatalities || A tornado destroyed hundreds of trees and damaged power-lines at Trawalla, near [[Beaufort, Victoria|Beaufort]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Jamali |first=Dellaram |url=http://www.thecourier.com.au/news/local/news/general/storm-destroys-hundreds-of-trees-at-trawalla/1902025.aspx/ |title=Storm destroys hundreds of trees at Trawalla |publisher=The Courier |date=2010-08-02 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | [[Penola, South Australia|Penola]] tornado || 31 July 2010 || South Australia || 1 || 0 fatalities || A tornado ripped through the main street of Penola in South-east South Australia, destroying at least four buildings and damaging many others. No injuries were reported.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gerritsen |first=Tim |url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2010/07/31/2969956.htm |title=Tornado rips through Penola – ABC South East SA – Australian Broadcasting Corporation |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=2010-07-31 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | [[Moama]] tornado || 10 August 2010 || New South Wales || 1 || 0 fatalities || A weak tornado was observed in the town of Moama in southern New South Wales, causing some minor damage<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.weatherzone.com.au/news/wild-weather-causes-mini-tornado/14787 |title=Weather News – Wild weather causes mini-tornado |publisher=Weatherzone.com.au |date=2010-08-11 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- |[[Whitton, New South Wales|Whitton]] tornado || 1 February 2011 || New South Wales || 1 || 0 fatalities || A tornado struck the town destroying a carport, damaging houses and trees.<ref>{{cite news|last=Delaney|first=Anne|first2=Chris|last2=Coleman|title=Dante's Tornado|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/photos/2011/02/04/3130051.htm|accessdate=7 February 2011|work=[[ABC Riverina]]|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=4 February 2011}}</ref> | |- | Yellow Water Billabong tornado || 11 February 2011 || Northern Territory || 1 || 0 fatalities || Footage of a tornado over Yellow Water [[billabong]] located in the [[Kakadu National Park]], in the [[Northern Territory]], was captured by a tour guide. There were no fatalities or injuries and damage limited to vegetation.<ref>{{citation|first=Nigel|last=Adlam|url=http://www.ntnews.com.au/article/2011/03/08/216671_ntnews.html|title=Tornado blows tourists away|accessdate=8 March 2011|publisher=[[Northern Territory News|NT News]]|date=8 March 2011}}</ref> | |- | [[Karratha, Western Australia|Karratha]] tornado || 21 February 2011 || Western Australia || 4 || 0 fatalities || The Karratha CBD was struck by a tornado, related to [[Tropical Cyclone Carlos]]. It reportedly uprooted large trees, tore roofs of houses and threw boats into the air. One person was injured by flying glass.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pilbaraecho.com.au/echo/content/view/2847/63/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110302153200/http://www.pilbaraecho.com.au/echo/content/view/2847/63/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-03-02 |title=Pilbara Echo :: A Part of Your Community now in Karratha & Port Hedland – Breaking News – Karratha town centre hit by tornado |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}}</ref> | |- | Magpie Valley tornado || 20 April 2011 || Victoria || 1 || 0 fatalities || A weak tornado was observed and photographed close to Ballarat's south eastern rural-urban fringe in the forestry area between [[Magpie, Victoria|Magpie]] and [[Sebastopol, Victoria|Sebastopol]]. No damage or injury was reported.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.thecourier.com.au/news/local/news/general/tornado-sweeps-across-ballarat/2140709.aspx |title=Tornado sweeps across Ballarat |publisher=The Courier |date=2011-04-20 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | [[Canning Vale, Western Australia|Canning Vale]] tornado || 20 May 2011 || Western Australia || 1 || 0 fatalities || Perth suburb of Canning Vale was struck by tornado, damaging a number of homes and a vehicle.<ref>{{cite news|last=Styles|first=Aja|title=Mini-tornado hits Canning Vale as storm tears through Perth|url=http://www.watoday.com.au/wa-news/minitornado-hits-canning-vale-as-storm-tears-through-perth-20110520-1evpl.html?from=watoday_sb|accessdate=20 May 2011|newspaper=WAtoday.com.au|date=20 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Rainy days for WA|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/05/20/3222149.htm?site=perth&section=news|accessdate=20 May 2011|work=702 ABC Perth|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=20 May 2011}}</ref> | |- | [[Red Rock, New South Wales|Red Rock]] tornado || 14 June 2011 || New South Wales || 1 || 0 fatalities || A waterspout/tornado unroofed at least two buildings including the Bowling Club, and damaged several others in Red Rock.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/latest/a/-/latest/9636620/tornado-hits-nsw-town|title=TORNADO HITS NSW TOWN |accessdate=May 8, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110618031312/http://au.news.yahoo.com/latest/a/-/latest/9636620/tornado-hits-nsw-town |archivedate=June 18, 2011 }}</ref> | |- | [[Bellbridge, Victoria|Bellbridge]] tornado || 9 November 2011 || Victoria || 1 || 0 fatalities || A tornado hit the Bellbridge and Bethanga areas, near [[Wodonga, Victoria|Wodonga]]. Several homes were severely damaged, some having their roofs removed, and several trees were uprooted.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dow |first=Aisha |url=http://www.bordermail.com.au/news/local/news/general/tornado-rips-apart-homes-lashes-villages/2351430.aspx?src=rss |title='Tornado' rips apart homes, lashes villages |publisher=The Border Mail |date=2011-11-08 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | [[Bacchus Marsh]] tornado || 25 December 2011 || Victoria || 2+ || 0 fatalities || A tornado hit Fiskville, west of Bacchus Marsh, Victoria. A second tornado was reported at [[Melton, Victoria|Melton]] from the same storm. Tennis-ball sized hail and flash-flooding also occurred with the storms, leaving an estimated damage bill in the millions of dollars.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/more-news/hail-barrage-inflicts-holiday-havoc-on-christmas-day/story-fn7x8me2-1226230033794|title=Tornado, storms strike Melbourne|author=|date=|work=heraldsun.com.au|accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref> | |- | [[Bredbo]] tornado || 20 January 2012 || New South Wales || 1 || 0 fatalities || A tornado hit the Bredbo area in the [[Snowy Mountains]] area of New South Wales.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/weather/tornado-hits-snowy-mountains-20120120-1q9z2.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | date=20 January 2012 | title=Tornado hits Snowy Mountains}}</ref> | |- | [[Townsville, Queensland|Townsville]] tornado || 20 March 2012 || Queensland || 1 || 0 fatalities || A tornado caused major structural and tree damage in the suburb of [[Vincent, Queensland|Vincent]]. Windspeed estimated at {{convert|160|-|200|kph|mph|abbr=on}} from damage analysis. Other suburbs affected were [[Garbutt, Queensland|Garbutt]], [[Gulliver, Queensland|Gulliver]], [[Aitkenvale, Queensland|Aitkenvale]], and [[Annandale, Queensland|Annandale]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jcu.edu.au/cts/publications/content/technical-reports/tech-report-no.-58-investigation-of-townsville-tornado-20-march-2012/view |title=Tech Report No 58 Investigation of Townsville Tornado, 20 March 2012 — Cyclone Testing Station (CTS) - James Cook University |publisher=Jcu.edu.au |date=2012-03-20 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.townsvillebulletin.com.au/article/2012/03/20/315531_news.html|title=Clean-up begins after storm's devastation |accessdate=March 21, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130506231549/http://www.townsvillebulletin.com.au/article/2012/03/20/315531_news.html |archivedate=May 6, 2013 }}</ref> | |- | Black Range tornado || 31 May 2012 || Victoria || 1 || 0 fatalities || A tornado struck the Black Range, near [[Stawell, Victoria|Stawell]], causing minor structural and tree damage.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.stawelltimes.com.au/news/local/news/general/tornado-strikes-black-ranges/2576468.aspx?storypage=1 |title=Tornado strikes Black Ranges | The Stawell Times-News |publisher=Stawelltimes.com.au |date=2012-05-31 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | [[Perth]] tornado outbreak || 7 June 2012 || Western Australia || 2-3 || 0 fatalities || Tornadoes struck the Perth suburbs of Dianella and Morley, damaging homes, trees and power lines. Light St and Marmion St in Dianella suffered the worst damage. Winds were measured at {{convert|180|kph|mph|abbr=on}}, leading meteorologists to categorise it as an F1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.perthnow.com.au/news/western-australia/mini-tornado-hits-light-street-dianella/story-e6frg13u-1226388792016|title=More wild weather expected this weekend|author=|date=|work=perthnow.com.au|accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref> A tornado also struck [[York, Western Australia|York]], {{convert|100|km|mi|abbr=on}} east of Perth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-06-07/mini-tornado-strikes-dianella/4058618 |title=Clean up continues after tornado's destruction – ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Abc.net.au |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> A total of 100 homes and buildings were damaged. | |- | Southern [[Tasmania]] tornado outbreak || 9 November 2012 || Tasmania || 2+ || 0 fatalities || Tornadoes reported on [[Mount Wellington (Tasmania)|Mount Wellington]] and [[Sorell, Tasmania|Sorell]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-11-09/tornado-warning-for-southern-tas/4362868?section=tas |title=Storm threat eases in Tasmania – ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation) |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=2012-11-09 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> | |- | Central [[Queensland]] tornado outbreak || 26–27 January 2013 || Queensland || >6 || >20 injured || Several tornadoes struck the [[Bundaberg, Queensland|Bundaberg]] region of Central Queensland on 26 January, associated with the remnants of [[Cyclone Oswald]]. The first struck [[Bargara, Queensland|Bargara]] at 1.00pm (AEST), tearing roofs from buildings, and injuring at least six people. [[Burnett Heads, Queensland|Burnett Heads]] was struck by three separate tornadoes, at 3.15pm and 6.05pm, and again at 6.30pm. Another tornado crossed the coast at Coonar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/environment/weather/tornadoes-hit-three-queensland-coastal-towns-20130126-2ddcm.html |title=Tornadoes hit Queensland coastal towns |publisher=Brisbanetimes.com.au |date=2013-01-26 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> A sixth tornado occurred at [[Burrum Heads]] on 27 January, whilst there were unconfirmed reports of a tornado at Bribie Island.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.theage.com.au/environment/weather/sixth-tornado-hits-southeast-queensland-20130127-2dehe.html | location=Melbourne | work=The Age | title=Sixth tornado hits southeast Queensland}}</ref>||F1 |- | Ballarat tornado || 31 January 2013 || Ballarat, Victoria || 1 || 0 || A small tornado swept through parts of Ballarat. Starting in Ballarat North where it caused the most damage, it rounded Black Hill, briefly crossing the CBD before sweeping across Ballarat East and continuing to Eureka in the east of the city. The tornado caused extensive and localised minor damage to houses and buildings, tearing away roofs, fences and garages, smashing windows, uprooting trees, destroying chimneys and cutting power to parts of the CBD and deactivating traffic lights. Wind gusts of over {{convert|80|kph|mph|abbr=on}} were recorded.<ref>{{cite web|last=Mcilroy |first=Tom |url=http://www.thecourier.com.au/story/1272148/mini-tornado-rips-through-ballarat-north/?cs=62 |title=‘Mini-tornado’ rips through Ballarat North |publisher=The Courier |date=2013-01-31 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/mini-tornado-damages-homes-causes-havoc-in-ballarat/story-e6frf7kx-1226566179361|title=Mini-tornado causes havoc in Ballarat|author=|date=|work=heraldsun.com.au|accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref><ref>[https://archive.is/20130219180236/http://www.weeklytimesnow.com.au/article/2013/02/01/558547_latest-news.html]</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Oliver |first=Jordan |url=http://www.thecourier.com.au/story/1272890/ballarat-east-family-counts-storm-damage-cost/?cs=62 |title=Ballarat East family counts storm damage cost |publisher=The Courier |date=2013-02-01 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref>||F1 |- | Sydney-Illawarra Tornado Outbreak || 23–24 February 2013 || New South Wales || 8 || 0 || A tornado with winds of up to {{convert|135|kph|mph|abbr=on}} was observed in Sydney's inner east causing extensive damage at [[Kirribilli]]. Damage was also observed at [[Chifley, New South Wales|Chifley]], [[Malabar, New South Wales|Malabar]] and [[Randwick, New South Wales|Randwick]]. The effects were most severe at Kirribilli where it removing roofs from houses, uprooted trees and damaging the Westpac Bank and the Sydney Flying Squadron.<ref>[http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/environment/weather/wild-weather-brings-floods-mini-tornadoes-20130224-2ez8p.html Wild weather brings floods, 'mini tornadoes'] Rachel Olding, ''[[Brisbane Times]]''. February 24, 2013</ref> Several tornadoes struck the Illawarra region south of [[Sydney]], New South Wales. Tornadoes occurred at [[Kiama]], [[Seven Mile Beach (New South Wales)|Seven Mile Beach]] to [[Nowra]] (rated F2 with wind speeds of up to {{convert|200|kph|mph|abbr=on}}<ref>[https://archive.is/20130410105059/http://www.2st.com.au/index.php/news/46445-study-shows-shoalhaven-tornado-had-200-kph-winds]</ref>), [[Jamberoo]] and [[Albion Park Rail]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Thompson |first=Angela |url=http://www.illawarramercury.com.au/story/1327933/gallery-south-coast-hit-by-family-of-tornadoes/?cs=298 |title=GALLERY: South Coast hit by 'family of tornadoes' |publisher=Illawarra Mercury |date=2013-02-26 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> The tornado at Kiama caused significant damage to homes.<ref>{{cite web|last=Webster |first=Michelle |url=http://www.illawarramercury.com.au/story/1328338/tornado-cut-a-destructive-path-along-coast/?cs=300 |title=Tornado cut a destructive path along coast |publisher=Illawarra Mercury |date=2013-02-27 |accessdate=2014-01-22}}</ref> Post event analysis confirmed 8 tornadoes, with 2 rated F0, 5 at F1 and 1 rated as F2.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://iri.columbia.edu/~tippett/SCC2/PostersArchive/2016SCCALLEN_TornadoClimPoster.pdf|title=The Tornado Climatology of Australia 1795-2014|last=Allen|first=John Terrence|last2=Allen|first2=Edwina Rose|date=2016|website=|publisher=Columbia University, New York|access-date=2016-04-21}}</ref>||F2 |- | Eastern Victoria tornado outbreak || 21 March 2013 || North-eastern Victoria and southern New South Wales || 7 || >20 injured || A total of 7 tornadoes touched down, one tornado rated at EF4 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/murray-twister-similar-in-destructive-force-to-the-deadly-oklahoma-city-tornado/story-fni0fit3-1226650586602|title=Tornado like an oncoming train|author=|date=|work=heraldsun.com.au|accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref> struck the towns of [[Koonoomoo, Victoria|Koonoomoo]], [[Cobram]], [[Barooga]], [[Mulwala]], [[Yarrawonga]], and [[Bundalong]], followed by a second tornado from the same storm at [[Rutherglen, Victoria|Rutherglen]] between 6:50-8:30pm ([[Time in Australia|AEDT]]). A tornado rated EF3 struck the towns of [[Tamleugh]], [[Euroa]] and [[Swanpool, Victoria|Swanpool]].<ref>{{cite web|title=F3 tornado devastates Murray Valley towns|url=http://www.ses.vic.gov.au/media/news/news-items/f2-tornado-devastates-murray-valley-towns|work=Victoria State Emergency Service|accessdate=22 March 2013|date=22 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130428151845/http://www.ses.vic.gov.au/media/news/news-items/f2-tornado-devastates-murray-valley-towns|archivedate=28 April 2013|df=}}</ref><ref name=ABC22Mar>{{cite news|title=Tornadoes tear through Victorian towns|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-03-21/tornadoes-tear-through-victorian-towns/4587648|accessdate=22 March 2013|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=22 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Disaster relief for tornado hit towns: PM|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/breaking-news/disaster-relief-for-tornado-hit-towns-pm/story-fn3dxiwe-1226604016610|accessdate=23 March 2013|newspaper=[[The Australian]]|date=23 March 2013|agency=[[Australian Associated Press|AAP]]}}</ref> Twenty people sustained injuries requiring hospitalisation, with one in a serious condition and two in a critical but stable condition.<ref>{{cite web|title=Paramedics respond following tornado UPDATED 0600|url=http://www.ambulance.vic.gov.au/About-Us/Media-Centre/News/20130322-Paramedics-respond-following-tornado.html|work=Ambulance Victoria|accessdate=22 March 2013|date=22 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130412111948/http://www.ambulance.vic.gov.au/About-Us/Media-Centre/News/20130322-Paramedics-respond-following-tornado.html|archivedate=12 April 2013|df=}}</ref> Roofs were ripped off homes, caravans upturned, the Barooga Post Office was heavily damaged and a petrol station was damaged at Euroa.<ref name=ABC22Mar/><ref>{{cite news|title=Locals describe tornado experience|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2013/03/22/3721335.htm|accessdate=22 March 2013|work=ABC Goulburn Murray|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=22 March 2013}}</ref> The initial EF4 is believed to have been the most powerful tornado to have ever hit Victoria. Further tornadoes touched down near [[Kerang]] (EF0), [[Benalla]] (EF0), and two near [[Mansfield, Victoria|Mansfield]] (EF0 and EF1).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B8YgBSDRzcTzSDYyWWM0RHNHUjA/edit|title=AMOStornadoevent_videos_06-coombs.wmv|author=|date=|work=google.com|accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref>||F3 |- | Ararat tornado || 22 October 2013 || [[Ararat, Victoria]] || 1 || 0 || A large storm cell over much of the state spawned what were likely shortly lived tornadoes in Ararat and [[Barnawartha]] in the state's north. In Ararat, a storage building was completely destroyed, and several other buildings were damaged including a hardware store and numerous homes sustained damage to roofs. Several trees were snapped or uprooted, sheds and fences levelled in a 500-metre damage path, mainly along McLellan Street.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/tornado-brings-havoc-to-victorian-town-of-ararat/story-e6frg6nf-1226745007027 | work=The Australian | title=Tornado brings havoc to Victorian town of Ararat | date=23 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Deborah Gough |url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/weather/minitornado-rips-through-ararat-as-storm-cells-cross-victoria-20131023-2vzv8.html |title='Mini-tornado' rips through Ararat as storm cells cross Victoria |publisher=Smh.com.au |date=2013-10-23 |accessdate=2014-01-23}}</ref> The Bureau of Meteorology described the phenomenon as either tornadoes<ref>{{cite web|author=EMMA D'AGOSTINO |url=http://www.mailtimes.com.au/story/1859580/ararat-storm-possibly-mini-tornado-bureau-of-meteorology/?cs=224 |title=Ararat storm possibly mini-tornado: Bureau of Meteorology | The Wimmera Mail-Times |publisher=Mailtimes.com.au |date=2013-10-23 |accessdate=2014-01-23}}</ref> or microbursts.||F1 |- | Hornsby CBD tornado || 18 November 2013 || Hornsby, New South Wales || 1 || 0 fatalities, 12 injured || Twelve people were injured by a tornado that struck the CBD area of Hornsby, New South Wales <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/hornsby-hit-by-mini-tornado-which-sounded-like-a-freight-train-and-ripped-the-roof-off-the-myer-building/news-story/7d529d6b5b7e45385bb11459df16e077|title='Mini tornado' rips off cinema roof|author=|date=|work=news.com.au|accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref> The Bureau of Meteorology confirmed the tornado event and they believe that it may have started as a water spout that was sighted offshore at Manly at 2:15pm weakening overland before intensifying and forming a tornado over Hornsby CBD at 2:46pm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/stores-closed-clean-up-continuing-in-hornsby-following-yesterdays-mini-tornado/news-story/658c8a5ad19ff049cf33144ca0e6776f|title=Hornsby tornado's Manly origins|author=|date=|work=dailytelegraph.com.au|accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref> Car dashcam footage captured the tornado as it crossed George street from the Westfield shopping centre across to the Railway Station.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AbJxArRomgw|title=Mini tornado in Hornsby N.S.W 18/11/2013|first=|last=bluedevil6k|date=18 November 2013|publisher=|accessdate=9 February 2017|via=YouTube}}</ref> Locals dubbed the event 'The Hornado'. ||F1 |- |New England tornadoes |23 November 2013 |New South Wales |6 |0 |Up to four tornadoes were suspected to have touched down in the [[New England, New South Wales|New England region]], one tornado had an {{convert|100|-|200|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide path and estimated winds of {{convert|160|kph|mph|abbr=on}} near [[Tenterden, New South Wales]] destroyed a home, caused extensive damage to property and uprooted trees. Storm chasers captured photographs and video footage of the tornado as it touched down from a wall cloud near BenLomond.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://video.au.msn.com/watch/video/guyra-tornado-caught-on-camera/x6ocmxx |title=Guyra tornado caught on camera on MSN Video |publisher=Video.au.msn.com |accessdate=2014-01-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/nation/tornado-wrecks-nsw-house/story-e6frg6nf-1226767047995 | work=The Australian | title=Tornado wrecks NSW house as storms continue in state | date=24 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Stewart |first=Janelle |url=http://www.guyraargus.com.au/story/1936634/tornadoes-touch-down/ |title=Tornadoes touch down |publisher=The Guyra Argus |date=2013-11-28 |accessdate=2014-01-23}}</ref> Six tornadoes of F0 to F1 intensity were confirmed.<ref name=":0" /> |F1 |- |Pakenham tornado |14 June 2014 |Victoria |1 |0 |A tornado was filmed as it roped out at [[Pakenham, Victoria|Pakenham]] south east of Melbourne at around midday on Saturday 14 June 2014.<ref>{{Citation|title = Rope cloud over pakenham|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vvAi4l6WvCw|date = 2014-06-14|accessdate = 2016-02-07|last = helen murdock}}</ref> |F0 |- |[[Perth]] Metro Tornadoes |14 July 2014 |Western Australia |2-4 |2 fatalities |As many as four tornadoes impacted the metropolitan area around Perth. A confirmed tornado caused significant damage to properties in [[Hilton, Western Australia|Hilton]] and [[O'Connor, Western Australia|O'Connor]], removing entire sections of roof structures to family homes, snapping wooden power poles and downing trees. Another tornado was confirmed to have damaged homes and downed trees in [[Claremont, Western Australia|Claremont]]. A third tornado is suspected to have been the cause of damage in [[Beeliar, Western Australia|Beeliar]]. Further south at [[Yallingup, Western Australia|Yallingup]] it is suspected that fourth tornado is responsible for damage including downed trees.<ref>{{Citation|title = Tornado Hits Perth {{!}} 7News Perth {{!}} 14/07/2013|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZWw3NE_izfQ|date = 2014-07-14|accessdate = 2016-02-07|last = 7newsPerth}}</ref> Two men with muscular dystrophy died in [[Beaconsfield, Affecting over 100 rural properties the tornado caused over $12 million of damage. Crop damage included over 1000 hectares of table or wine grapes, 790 hectares of citrus, and combined 40 hectares of eggplants, capsicums and melons. The Bureau of Meteorology concluded a tornado spawned by a supercell thunderstorm had left a band of damage from [[Yelta, Victoria|Yelta]], Victoria to north of Gol Gol in southwest New South Wales. The damage path was estimated at approximately 20 kilometers in length an possibly up to 2 km wide, along which the tornado had uprooted and snapped trees, damaged vineyards, and ripped roofs off houses and sheds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bom.gov.au/australia/stormarchive/ |title=Severe Storms Archive |website=Bom.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2017-02-28}}</ref> |F1 |- |[[Bombala, New South Wales|Bombala]] tornado |24 January 2015 |New South Wales |1 |0 |A tornado impacted the New South Wales town of Bombala on Saturday 24 January 2015, leaving damage to roofs, sheds, and scattering debris across the town.<ref>{{cite web|title = Tornado hits Bombala|url = http://www.bombalatimes.com.au/story/2838639/tornado-hits-bombala/|website = Bombala Times|access-date = 2016-02-02|first = Fairfax Regional|last = Media}}</ref> It was witnessed by locals and filmed by one.<ref>{{Citation|title = Tornado in Bombala NSW - 26/01/2015|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vodBpz9cweI|date = 2015-01-28|accessdate = 2016-02-02|last = Sam Dyer}}</ref> |F0 |- |[[Creswick, Victoria|Creswick]] tornado |13 February 2015 |Victoria |1 |0 |A tornado was filmed northwest of Creswick, Victoria.<ref>{{Citation|title = TORNADO FRIDAY 13th {{sic|nolink=y|FEB|UARY}} 2015 NORTH WEST OF CRESWICK VIC|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5VT8sQO9dHA|date = 2015-11-06|accessdate = 2016-02-02|last = Luke Nights Nights}}</ref> |F0 |- |[[Pokolbin, New South Wales|Pokolbin]] tornado |15 February 2015 |Hunter Valley, New South Wales |1 |0 |A tornado left a trail of destruction through a Pokolbin winery.
