revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=September 2016}} [[File:Ballast water en.svg|thumb|Ballast water discharge from other sides of the world cause a certain type of pollution different from an emission type pollution as it introduces [[invasive species]] that can literally cause domestic species to go extinct.]] After delivering their cargo, empty commercial ships need to take up water from the port of arrival in order to maintain stability and ensure safe navigation conditions before heading back to the port of departure. This water, called [[ballast water]], which contains aquatic organisms typical of the port of arrival, is stored in [[ballast tank]]s and is ultimately discharged at the port of departure when the ship is ready to be re-loaded. During this process, aquatic organisms capable of surviving in ballast water are released into new environments and can therefore become invasive species, causing serious economic and public health issues.<ref>{{cite web|title=Silent Invasion|publisher= WWF International |year=2009|url=http://www.wwf.de/fileadmin/fm-wwf/Publikationen-PDF/Study_Silent_Invasion.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Control and management of ballast water |year=2012|url=https://www.gov.uk/guidance/control-and-management-of-ballast-water |publisher=gov.uk}}</ref>
Following the ratification of the [[International Maritime Organization]] (IMO)’s Ballast Water Management (BWM) Convention, commercial ships will have to treat their ballast water in order to comply with maximum discharge standards established for organisms in different size categories (IMO’s D-2 Standards and [[US Coast Guard]] Standards). However, some organisms are capable of surviving or even recovering after harsh treatments, leading to regrowth in ballast water tanks before discharge. In order to minimise regrowth and hence avoid exceeding discharge limits, different criteria such as duration of the journey, ballast water tanks capacity and water flow rate at intake and discharge, among others, should be considered when choosing an appropriate type-approved ballast water treatment systems (BWTS).
== Ballast water treatment systems (BWTS)== {{asof|2012}}, no single ballast water treatment method, or even a combination of primary (e.g. mechanical/physical separation) and secondary (e.g. active chemical substances) methods, can remove or inactivate all organisms in ballast water.<ref name=Chase2001>Chase, C., Reilly, C., Pederson, J. (2001) Marine bioinvasions fact sheet: ballast water treatment options. MIT Sea Grant Centre for Coastal Resources, Cambridge, MA. [http://massbay.mit.edu/resources/pdf/ballast-treat.pdf Marine bioinvasions fact sheet].</ref><ref name=Waite2003>Waite, T.D., Kazumi, J., Lane, P.V.Z., Farmer, L.L., Smith, S.G., Smith, S.L., Hitchcock, G., Capo, T.R. (2003). Waite, T.D., Kazumi, J., Lane, P.V.Z., Farmer, L.L., Smith, S.G., Smith, S.L., Hitchcock, G., Capo, T.R. (2003). [http://www.int-res.com/articles/meps2003/258/m258p051.pdf “Removal of natural populations of marine plankton by a large-scale ballast water treatment system”]. ''Marine Ecology Progress Series'' '''258''': 51-63.</ref><ref>Tsolaki, E., Diamadopoulos, E. (2010). [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jctb.2276/abstract “Technologies for ballast water treatment: a review”]. ''Journal of Chemical Technology and Biotechnology'' '''85''': 19-32.</ref><ref name=Gregg2009>Gregg, M., Rigby, G., Hallegraeff, G.M. (2009). [http://iwlearn.net/publications/ballastwater_planktonmanagement.pdf “Review of two decades of progress in the development of management options for reducing or eradicating phytoplankton, zooplankton and bacteria in ship’s ballast water”]. ''Aquatic Invasions'' '''4''', 521-565.</ref><ref>Veldhuis, M., ten Hallers, C., de la Rivière, E.B., Fuhr, F., Finke, J., Stehouwer, P.P., van de Star, I., van Slooten, C. (2010). [http://globallast.imo.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/EmergingBallastWater.pdf “Ballast water treatment systems: “Old” and “New” ones”]. In: Emerging ballast water management systems. Proceedings of the IMO-WMU Research and Development Forum, Malmö, Sweden.</ref><ref>Ibrahim, A.M., El-Naggar, M.M. (2012). [http://www.idosi.org/mejsr/mejsr12(7)12/11.pdf “Ballast water review: impacts, treatments and management”]. ''Middle-East Journal of Scientific Research'' '''12''': 976-84.</ref> Furthermore, some treatments are more effective in removing microorganisms such as bacteria, whereas others are better at killing larger organisms such as [[phytoplankton]] (e.g. [[diatoms]]) and [[zooplankton]] (e.g. [[copepods]]).<ref name=Chase2001 /><ref name=Gregg2009 /><ref>Wright, D., Dawson, R. (2002). [http://globallast.imo.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/RDDirectory8thEd.pdf “Shipboard Trial of Primary and Secondary Ballast Water Treatment Systems”]. In: Ballast Water Treatment R&D Directory.</ref><ref name=Lloyds2015>Ballast water treatment technologies and current system availability (2015). Part of [http://www.lr.org/en/marine/consulting/environmental-services/ballastwatermanagement.aspx Lloyd's Register's Understanding Ballast Water Management Series].</ref>
There are currently over 50 IMO type-approved<!--33 CFR Part 151--> BWTS on the market to choose from. These include the use of technologies such as [[UV irradiation]], [[ozonation]], [[electrochlorination]], hydrodynamic [[cavitation]] and [[ultrasound]], among others, applied as stand-alone or combined treatments.<ref name=Gregg2009 /><ref name=Lloyds2015 /> The [[US Coast Guard]] requires BWTS as per 46 CFR 162.060,<!--stricter than IMO--><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ecfr.gov/cgi-bin/text-idx?SID=709031ac82e912835f355ff5cdb0c476&mc=true&node=sp46.6.162.162_1060&rgn=div6 |title=Title 46 → Chapter I → Subchapter Q → Part 162 → Subpart 162.060 |last= |first= |date=December 6, 2016 |website= |publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]] |access-date=December 8, 2016 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://homeport.uscg.mil/mycg/portal/ep/channelView.do?channelId=-18366&channelPage=%252Fep%252Fchannel%252Fdefault.jsp&pageTypeId=13489 |title=Homeport: Ballast Water Management Program|publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]] |date= |access-date=December 8, 2016 }}</ref> and began approving in 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://mariners.coastguard.dodlive.mil/2016/12/02/marine-safety-center-issues-ballast-water-management-system-bwms-type-approval-certificate-optimarin-as/ |title=Marine Safety Center issues Ballast Water Management System (BWMS) type-approval certificate to Optimarin AS |last= |first= |date=December 2, 2016 |website= |publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]] |access-date=December 8, 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
== Regrowth == Surviving organisms have the potential to regrow after treatment and, depending on the duration of the voyage and the prevailing conditions, this regrowth could lead to exceeding the maximum number of aquatic organisms that can be discharged according to the established standards.
Both phytoplankton and zooplankton have been shown to be capable of surviving in ballast water tanks for up to 23 days.<ref>Kang, J.H., Hyun, B.G., Shin, K. (2010). [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0025326X09004032?np=y “Phytoplankton viability in ballast water from international commercial ships berthed at ports in Korea”]. ''Marine Pollution Bulletin'' '''60''': 230-237.</ref><ref>Gollasch, S., Lenz, J., Dammer, M., Andres, H.G. (2000). [http://plankt.oxfordjournals.org/content/22/5/923.full.pdf+html “Survival of tropical ballast water organisms during a cruise from the Indian Ocean to the North Sea”]. ''Journal of Plankton Research'' '''22''': 923-937.</ref> There is also evidence showing that different phytoplanktonic organisms can regrow within 4 to 20 days of incubating in favourable conditions.<ref>Stehouwer, P.P., Fuhr, F., Veldhuis, M. (2010). [http://globallast.imo.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/EmergingBallastWater.pdf “A novel approach to determine ballast water vitality and viability after treatment”]. In: Emerging ballast water management systems. Proceedings of the IMO-WMU Research and Development Forum, Malmö, Sweden.</ref><ref>Stehouwer, P.P., Buma, A., Peperzak, L. (2015). [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09593330.2015.1021858?journalCode=tent20 “A comparison of six different ballast water treatment systems based on UV radiation, electrochlorination and chlorine dioxide”]. ''Environmental Technology'' '''36''': 2094-2104.</ref><ref>van der Star, I., Liebich, V., Stehouwer, P.P. (2011). [http://globallast.imo.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/RD_Turkey_2011.pdf “The forgotten fraction: The importance of organisms smaller than 10 µm when evaluating ballast water treatment systems”]. ''Ballast Water Management Systems'' '''41'''.</ref><ref>Liebich, V., Stehouwer, P.P., Veldhuis, M. (2012). [http://www.aquaticinvasions.net/2012/AI_2012_1_Liebich_etal.pdf “Regrowth of potential invasive phytoplankton following UV-based ballast water treatment”]. ''Aquatic Invasions'' '''7''': 29-36.</ref><ref>Martínez, L.F., Mahamud, M.M., Lavín, A.G., Bueno, J.L. (2013). [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0025326X12005577 “The regrowth of phytoplankton cultures after UV disinfection”]. ''Marine Pollution Bulletin'' '''67''': 152-157.</ref> Bacteria that survive treatment have an even higher potential for regrowth, as they benefit from the death of other organisms in two different ways (i) nutrients essential for bacterial growth are released in the form of dissolved organic matter and, (ii) there is a decrease in the number of predators that would otherwise eat them.<ref>Carney, K.J., Delany, J.E., Sawant, S., Mesbahi, E. (2011). [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0025326X11001512 “The effects of prolonged darkness on temperate and tropical marine phytoplankton, and their implications for ballast water risk management”]. ''Marine Pollution Bulletin'' '''62''': 1233-1244.</ref><ref>Lasternas, S., Agustí, S. (2014). [http://www.biogeosciences.net/11/6377/2014/bg-11-6377-2014.pdf “The percentage of living bacterial cells related to organic carbon release from senescent oceanic phytoplankton”]. ''Biogeosciences'' '''11''': 6377-6387.</ref><ref>Buchan, A., LeCleir, G.R., Gulvik, C.A., González, J.M. (2014). [http://www.nature.com/nrmicro/journal/v12/n10/abs/nrmicro3326.html “Master recyclers: features and functions of bacteria associated with phytoplankton blooms”]. ''Nature Reviews Microbiology'' '''12''': 686-698.</ref><ref name=Hess2010>Hess-Erga, O.K., Blomvågnes-Bakke, B., Vadstein, O. (2010). [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0043135410004562 “Recolonization by heterotrophic bacteria after UV irradiation or ozonation of seawater; a simulation of ballast water treatment”]. ''Water Research'' '''44''': 5439-5449.</ref> Overall, bacterial regrowth has been observed after 18 hrs to 7 days of applying different treatments.<ref name=Waite2003 /><ref name=Hess2010 /><ref>Li, D., Zeng, S., Gu, A.Z., He, M., Shi, H. (2013). [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1001074212601764 “Inactivation, reactivation and regrowth of indigenous bacteria in reclaimed water after chlorine disinfection of a municipal wastewater treatment plant”]. ''Journal of Environmental Sciences'' '''25''': 1319-1325.</ref><ref>van Slooten, C., Peperzak, L., Buma, A.G. (2015). [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09593330.2014.951401?journalCode=tent20 “Assessment of didecyldimethylammonium chloride as a ballast water treatment method”]. ''Environmental Technology'' '''36''': 435-449.</ref><ref>First, M.R., Drake, L.A. (2014). [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10811-013-0049-9 “Life after treatment: detecting living microorganisms following exposure to UV light and chlorine dioxide”]. ''Journal of Applied Phycology'' '''26''': 227-235.</ref>
Therefore, the scientific evidence currently available supports the idea that it is not an issue of “IF regrowth” but “WHEN regrowth”.
== Considerations == Timescales are very important when considering regrowth. For instance, if ballast water is treated at intake and held in ballast tanks for over a week before discharge, then the organisms surviving the treatment could have enough time to increase in numbers and potentially exceed discharge standards before the end of the voyage.
Every BWTS has its advantages and disadvantages <ref name=Lloyds2015 /> and ship owners and ship operators should consider the benefits and limitations of different systems before making an educated choice based on their requirements. The issue of regrowth should be taken seriously and should be taken into account when choosing an appropriate BWTS.<ref>Grob, C., Pollet, B.G. (2016). [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0025326X16302739 “Regrowth in ship’s ballast water tanks: think again!”]. Accepted for publication in ''Marine Pollution Bulletin''.</ref>
== See also == * [[Ballast Water Management]] * [[Environmental impact of shipping]]
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Ocean pollution]] [[Category:Environmental impact of shipping]]

revision.text:
{{Update|date=March 2015}} The '''Reykjavík Green Days''' is an annual event which takes place in [[Reykjavík]], [[Iceland]]. This event was founded by a group of students at the University of Iceland in the Environmental and Natural resources program.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nemendafelog.hi.is/gaia/about-us/|title=About Us {{!}} Gaia|website=nemendafelog.hi.is|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-03}}</ref>
"Gaia", as the group is known, aims to raise awareness and stimulate citizens, businesses, non-governmental organizations, local authorities and other urban actors to improve the environment's quality by implementing changes in behavior.
It's considered by the Reykjavík town Council an environmental education initiative that encourages all stakeholders to take steps towards becoming more environmentally responsible.
The initiave has been organized by the SEED Iceland association in collaboration with other minor local institutions. The staff has been made up of people with 9 nationalities<ref>[http://seedsiceland.webs.com/credits.htmFrom The initiative credits; Reykjavík Green days staff]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}: Sumi Ahn (South Korea), Judit Alonso (Spain/France), Aurelia de Callatay (Belgium), Juan Antonio Corbalan Liarte (Spain), François Gentil (France, Waste management day and Critical Mass overseer), Andrea Gori (Italy, Webmaster and Critical Mass overseer), Angels Hernandez (Spain), Sophie Muller (France), Tommaso Papini (Italy), Mauro Pitzalis (Italy, supervisor for the children activities), Felipe Sanchez (Colombia/Denmark, Green days supervisor and Efficient use of energy resources day overseer), Edward Williams (England, Film festival debate-moderator).</ref> and so the event has been a relevant tourist attraction. The most important happening of the 2009 edition was the [[Critical mass|Reykjavík critical mass]], which was actually the first one in Iceland.<ref>[http://www.icelandreview.com/icelandreview/daily_news/?cat_id=16539&ew_0_a_id=338007 Iceland review online]</ref>
==Notes== <references/>
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20111008132430/http://www.seedsiceland.webs.com/ Web site of the event]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Reykjavik Green Days}} [[Category:Environmental awareness days]] [[Category:August observances]]
{{Environment-stub}} {{Iceland-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''seasonally adjusted annual rate''' (SAAR) is a rate that is adjusted to take into account typical seasonal fluctuations in data and is expressed as an annual total. SAARs are used for data affected by [[seasonality]], when it could be misleading to directly compare different times of the year.
SAARs are often used for car sales.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/ALTSALES |title=Light Weight Vehicle Sales: Autos and Light Trucks|publisher=[[Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis]]|date=9 November 2016|accessdate=15 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/g17/mvsf.htm |title=Federal Reserve Seasonal Factors for Domestic Auto and Truck Production: formulas|publisher=[[Federal Reserve]]|date=1 April 2016|accessdate=15 November 2016}}</ref> Other examples of when SAARs could be used are occupancy rates at ski resorts, which are higher in the winter, or sales of ice cream, which are higher in the summer. Sales between seasons can be more easily compared using seasonally adjusted rates. The SAAR is calculated by dividing the unadjusted annual rate for the month by its seasonality factor and multiplying by 12 to create an annual rate. (Quarterly data would be multiplied by 4.)
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.investopedia.com/terms/s/saar.asp Investopedia's entry on the SAAR] * [https://www.economy.com/support/blog/buffet.aspx?did=B202381E-BADD-4AC0-923A-6451642D2489 Moody's Analytics Buffet: SAAR] * [http://www.readyratios.com/reference/analysis/seasonally_adjusted_annual_rate_saar.html What Does Seasonally Adjusted Annual Rate (SAAR) Mean?] * [https://people.duke.edu/~rnau/411seas.htm Seasonal adjustment], Duke University
== See also == *[[Seasonal adjustment]]
[[Category:Economic data]] [[Category:Seasonality]] [[Category:Time series]]
{{economic-term-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox physical quantity | name = Specific energy | unit = [[joule|J]]/[[kilogram|kg]] | basequantities = m<sup>2</sup>/s<sup>2</sup> | symbols = | derivations = e = [[energy|E]]/[[mass|m]] }}
::''[[Energy density]] has tables of specific energies of devices and materials.''
'''Specific energy''' is [[energy]] per unit [[mass]]. (It is also sometimes called "energy density," though "energy density" more precisely means [[energy density|energy per unit volume]].) It is used to quantify, for example, stored [[heat]] and other [[thermodynamic properties]] of substances such as [[specific internal energy]], [[specific enthalpy]], specific [[Gibbs free energy]], and specific [[Helmholtz free energy]]. It may also be used for the [[kinetic energy]] or [[potential energy]] of a body. Specific energy is an [[intensive property]], whereas energy and mass are [[extensive property|extensive properties]].
The [[International System of Units|SI]] unit for specific energy is the [[joule]] per [[kilogram]] (J/kg). Other units still in use in some contexts are the [[kilocalorie]] per gram (Cal/g or kcal/g), mostly in food-related topics, [[watt hour]]s per kilogram in the field of batteries, and the [[Imperial System|Imperial unit]] [[BTU]] per [[pound (mass)|pound]] (BTU/lb), in some [[engineering]] and applied technical fields.<ref name=Heselton> Kenneth E. Heselton (2004), [https://books.google.com/books?id=8y0qRQl7XDEC&pg=PA153 "Boiler Operator's Handbook"]. Fairmont Press, 405 pages. {{ISBN|0881734357}} </ref> The [[gray (unit)|gray]] and [[sievert]] are specialized measures for specific energy absorbed by body tissues in the form of [[radiation]]. The following table shows the factors for converting to J/kg:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Unit!! SI equivalent |- |kcal/g<ref>Using the thermochemical calorie.</ref> || 4.184 MJ/kg |- |Wh/kg || 3.6 kJ/kg |- |kWh/kg || 3.6 MJ/kg |- |Btu/lb<ref>Using the definition based on the International Steam Table calorie.</ref> || 2.326 kJ/kg |- |Btu/lb<ref>Using the definition based on the thermochemical calorie.</ref> || ca. 2.32444 kJ/kg |}
The concept of specific energy is related to but distinct from the [[chemistry|chemical]] notion of ''molar'' energy, that is energy per [[mole (unit)|mole]] of a substance, which uses units of energy per mole, such as J/[[mole (unit)|mol]], kJ/mol, or the older (but still widely used) [[kilocalorie|kcal]]/mol.<ref name=Lesz> Jerzy Leszczynski (2011), [https://books.google.com/books?id=aJn6UBl2YCwC&pg=PA1238 "Handbook of Computational Chemistry"]. Springer, 1430 pages. {{ISBN|940070710X}} </ref>
For a table giving the specific energy of many different fuels as well as batteries, see the article [[Energy density]].
==Energy density of food== {{Main|Food energy}}
Energy density is the amount of energy per mass or volume of food. The energy density of a food can be determined from the label by dividing the energy per serving (usually in [[kilojoule]]s or [[food calorie]]s) by the serving size (usually in grams,<!-- or ounces?--> milliliters or fluid ounces). Energy density is thus expressed in cal/g, kcal/g, J/g, kJ/g, cal/mL, kcal/mL, J/mL, or kJ/mL. The "calorie" commonly used in nutritional contexts is the kilogram-calorie (abbreviated "Cal" and sometimes called the "dietary calorie", "food calorie" or "Calorie" with a capital "C"). This is equivalent to a thousand gram-calories (abbreviated "cal") or one kilocalorie (kcal). Because food energy is commonly measured in Calories, the energy density of food is commonly called "caloric density".<ref>{{Cite news|last=Stevens|first=Heidi |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-04-19/features/sc-food-0416-calories-20100419_1_calorie-density-caloric-density-fiber |title=Consider caloric density for weight loss|work= [[Chicago Tribune]]|date=April 19, 2010}}</ref>
Energy density measures the energy released when the food is [[metabolized]] by a healthy organism when it ingests the food (see [[food energy]] for calculation) and the food is metabolized with oxygen, into waste products such as [[carbon dioxide]] and water. Besides [[ethanol|alcohol]] the only sources of food energy are [[carbohydrate]]s, [[fat]]s and [[protein]]s, which make up ninety percent of the dry weight of food.<ref name="merck">{{cite web|url=http://www.merck.com/mmhe/sec12/ch152/ch152b.html |title=Carbohydrates, Proteins, and Fats: Overview of Nutrition|work= The Merck Manual}}</ref> Therefore, [[water]] content is the most important factor in energy density. Carbohydrates provide four calories per gram (17 kJ/g), and proteins offer slightly less at 16kJ/g whereas fat provides nine calories per gram (38 kJ/g),<ref name="merck" /> {{frac|2|1|4}} times as much energy. Fats contain more carbon-carbon and carbon-hydrogen bonds than carbohydrates or proteins and are therefore richer in energy.<ref>{{cite book|last=Wilson|first=David L.|title=11th Hour: Introduction to Biology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YApiST6qvbgC&pg=PA40&dq=lipids+carbon-hydrogen+bonds&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ofdVUoykB4K49gSr74CQCg&ved=0CFQQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=lipids%20carbon-hydrogen%20bonds&f=false|year=2009|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]|isbn=9781444313222|page=40}}</ref> Foods that derive most of their energy from fat have a much higher energy density than those that derive most of their energy from carbohydrates or proteins, even if the water content is the same. Nutrients with a lower absorption, such as [[fiber]] or [[sugar alcohol]]s, lower the energy density of foods as well. A moderate energy density would be 1.6 to 3 calories per gram (7–13 kJ/g); salmon, lean meat, and bread would fall in this category. High-energy foods would have more than three calories per gram and include crackers, cheese, dark chocolate, and peanuts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.okinawaprogram.com/pdf/caloric_density_pyramid.pdf |title=The Okinawa Diet: Caloric Density Pyramid |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090509033559/http://www.okinawaprogram.com/pdf/caloric_density_pyramid.pdf |archivedate=May 9, 2009 }}</ref>
==Fuel== {{Main|Energy density}} Energy density is sometimes useful for comparing fuels. For example, [[liquid hydrogen]] fuel has a higher specific energy (energy per unit mass) than [[gasoline]] does, but a much lower volumetric energy density.
==Astrodynamics== [[Specific mechanical energy]], rather than simply energy, is often used in [[astrodynamics]], because gravity changes the kinetic and potential specific energies of a vehicle in ways that are independent of the mass of the vehicle, consistent with the [[conservation of energy]] in a [[Newton's law of universal gravitation|Newtonian gravitational system]].
The specific energy of an object such as a [[meteoroid]] falling on the earth from outside the earth's gravitational well is at least one half the square of the [[escape velocity]] of 11.2 km/s. This comes to 63 MJ/kg (15 kcal/g, or 15 tonnes [[TNT equivalent]] per tonne). [[Comet]]s have even more energy, typically moving with respect to the sun, when in our vicinity, at about the square root of two times the speed of the earth. This comes to 42 km/s, or a specific energy of 882 MJ/kg. The speed relative to the earth may be more or less, depending on direction. Since the speed of the earth around the sun is about 30 km/s, a comet's speed relative to the earth can range from 12 to 72 km/s, the latter corresponding to 2592 MJ/kg. If a comet with this speed fell to the earth it would gain another 63 MJ/kg, yielding a total of 2655 MJ/kg with a speed of 72.9 km/s. Since the equator is moving at about 0.5 km/s, the impact speed has an upper limit of 73.4 km/s, giving an upper limit for the specific energy of a comet hitting the earth of about 2690 MJ/kg.
If the [[Hale-Bopp]] comet (50 km in diameter) had hit the earth, it would have vaporized the oceans and sterilized the surface of the earth.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The end of life on Earth|journal=[[New Scientist]]|date=Jun 4, 2016|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030760-300-the-end-what-will-become-of-earth-and-all-that-lives-here}}</ref>
==Miscellaneous== * [[Kinetic energy]] per unit mass: {{frac2|1|2}}''v''<sup>2</sup>, where ''v'' is the speed (giving J/kg when ''v'' is in m/s). See also [[Projectile#Typical projectile speeds|kinetic energy per unit mass of projectiles]]. * [[Potential energy]] with respect to gravity, close to earth, per unit mass: ''gh'', where ''g'' is the acceleration due to gravity ([[standard gravity|standardized]] as ~9.8<!--0655--> m/s<sup>2</sup>) and ''h'' is the height above the reference level (giving J/kg when ''g'' is in m/s<sup>2</sup> and ''h'' is in m). * [[Heat]]: energies per unit mass are [[specific heat capacity]] times [[temperature]] difference, and [[Latent heat|specific melting heat]], and [[Standard enthalpy change of vaporization|specific heat of vaporization]]
== See also == * [[Energy density]] * [[Specific power (disambiguation)|Specific power]] * [[Heating value]] * [[Specific orbital energy]]
== References == {{Reflist}} * {{cite book |first1=Yunus A. |last1=Çengel |first2=Robert H.|last2= Turner |title=Fundamentals of Thermal-Fluid Sciences |publisher=McGraw Hill |year=2005 |isbn=0-07-297675-6}}

revision.text:
'''Sturgeon River''' may refer to any of the following streams in the U.S. state of Michigan:
* [[Sturgeon River (Delta County, Michigan)]] — The Sturgeon River rises as outflow of Sixteenmile Lake in [[Alger County, Michigan|Alger County]] at {{coord|46|17|35|N|86|46|00|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}} and flows primarily southward into the [[Big Bay de Noc]] at {{coord|45|50|17|N|86|40|01|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}}.<ref>{{gnis|1621807|Sturgeon River (Delta County)}}</ref> ** The '''West Branch Sturgeon River''' rises at {{coord|46|09|56|N|86|43|46|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}} and flows southeast into the main stream at {{coord|46|08|43|N|86|41|14|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}}.<ref>{{gnis|1622108|West Branch Sturgeon River (Delta County)}}</ref> ** A post office named Sturgeon River opened near the mouth of the river on July 23, 1891. The name was changed to St. Jacques on June 22, 1904. It closed on November 30, 1913, re-opened April 11, 1919, and was discontinued on July 31, 1955.<ref>{{gnis|Saint Joseph's (sic) Post Office (historical)}}</ref> * [[Sturgeon River (Houghton County, Michigan)]] — The Sturgeon River rises in [[Baraga County, Michigan|Baraga County]] at {{coord|46|35|12|N|88|16|05|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}} near [[Nestoria, Michigan|Nestoria]] and empties into [[Portage Lake (Keweenaw)|Portage Lake]] in the Keweenaw Waterway at {{coord|47|02|06|N|88|29|18|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}}.<ref>{{gnis|1621808|Sturgeon River (Houghton County)}}</ref> ** The '''West Branch Sturgeon River''' rises in western [[Houghton County, Michigan|Houghton County]] at {{coord|46|39|58|N|88|49|20|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}} and enters the main branch at {{coord|46|48|40|N|88|37|57|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}} at [[Pelkie, Michigan|Pelkie]].<ref>{{gnis|1622109|West Branch Sturgeon River (Houghton County)}}</ref> [[File:sturgeonriver.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The Sturgeon River (Cheboygan County)]] * [[Sturgeon River (Cheboygan County, Michigan)]] — The Sturgeon River rises in [[Otsego County, Michigan|Otsego County]] near [[Gaylord, Michigan|Gaylord]] and flows into [[Burt Lake]] in the community of [[Indian River, Michigan|Indian River]]. A channel formerly flowed into the [[Indian River (Mullett Lake)|Indian River]] at {{coord|45|24|47|N|84|36|36|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}}, though the main course of the river now empties directly into Burt Lake.<ref>{{gnis|638990|Sturgeon River (Cheboygan County)}}</ref> ** The '''West Branch Sturgeon River''' rises in southeast [[Charlevoix County, Michigan|Charlevoix County]] at {{coord|45|07|49|N|84|47|55|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}} and flows into the main stream at {{coord|45|16|19|N|84|36|03|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}} in [[Wolverine, Michigan|Wolverine]].<ref>{{gnis|1616075|West Branch Sturgeon River (Cheboygan County)}}</ref> ** The [[Little Sturgeon River]] rises in [[Cheboygan County, Michigan|Cheboygan County]] northeast of Wolverine at {{coord|45|17|55|N|84|33|37|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}} and flows north on a course generally parallel to the Sturgeon River. The mouth of the Little Sturgeon River is at {{coord|45|24|19|N|84|36|32|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}} on the former channel of the Sturgeon River that into the Indian River.<ref>{{gnis|630778|Little Sturgeon River}}</ref> * [[Sturgeon River (Dickinson County, Michigan)]] — The Sturgeon River rises from the confluence of the East and West branches at {{coord|45|55|19|N|87|47|46|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}} and empties into the [[Menominee River]] at {{coord|45|45|03|N|87|52|02|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}} near [[Norway, Michigan|Norway]].<ref>{{gnis|1625067|Sturgeon River (Dickinson County)}}</ref> ** The '''East Branch Sturgeon River''' rises at {{coord|46|06|08|N|87|58|08|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}}<ref>{{gnis|625153|East Branch Sturgeon River}}</ref> in central Dickinson County. ** The '''West Branch Sturgeon River''' rises in west central Dickinson County at {{coord|46|04|52|N|88|04|43|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}}.<ref>{{gnis|1616076|West Branch Sturgeon River (Dickinson County)}}</ref> *** The '''North Branch Sturgeon River''' rises at {{coord|46|06|26|N|88|02|31|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}} also in west central Dickinson County and flows into the West Branch at {{coord|46|03|31|N|88|00|00|W|region:US-MI_type:river_source:GNIS}}.<ref>{{gnis|633540|North Branch Sturgeon River}}</ref>

{{About|the 1964 novel|other uses|Flight of the Phoenix (disambiguation)}} {{refimprove|date=August 2013}} {{infobox book | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = The Flight of the Phoenix | title_orig = | translator = | image = Flight of the Phoenix book.jpg | image_size = | caption = First edition cover | author = [[Elleston Trevor]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = | published = 1964 by [[Harper & Row]] | media_type = Print ([[Hardback]]) | pages = 242 pp | oclc = 1280808 | dewey = 823.914 | congress = PR6039.R518 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''The Flight of the Phoenix''''' is a 1964 novel by [[Elleston Trevor]]. The plot involves the crash of a transport aircraft in the middle of a [[desert]] and the survivors' desperate attempt to save themselves. The book was the basis for the 1965 film ''[[The Flight of the Phoenix (1965 film)|The Flight of the Phoenix]]'' starring [[James Stewart]] and the 2004 [[remake]] entitled ''[[Flight of the Phoenix (2004 film)|Flight of the Phoenix]]''. ''The Flight of the Phoenix'' came at the midpoint of Trevor's career and led to a bidding war over its film rights.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kirjasto.sci.fi/etrevor.htm |title=Elleston Trevor |website=Books and Writers ''(kirjasto.sci.fi)'' |first=Petri |last=Liukkonen |publisher=Kuusankoski Public Library |location=Finland |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080926061423/http://www.kirjasto.sci.fi/etrevor.htm |archivedate=26 September 2008 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Plot summary== Pilot Frank Towns and navigator Lew Moran are ferrying a mixed bag of passengers out of the Jebel oil town of the Libyan desert, among them oil workers, a couple of British soldiers, and a German who was visiting his brother. An unexpected sandstorm forces the aircraft down, damaging it, killing two of the men, and severely injuring the German. In the book, the action takes place in the [[Libya]]n part of the [[Sahara]].<ref>[http://search.barnesandnoble.com/The-Flight-of-the-Phoenix/Elleston-Trevor/e/9780060762223 "Flight of the Phoenix by Elleston Trevor (Mass Market Paperback - Reissue) Book review."] ''barnesandnoble.com''. Retrieved: May 29, 2009.</ref>
The survivors wait for rescue but begin to worry, as the storm has blown them far off course, away from where searchers would look for them. After several days, Captain Harris marches toward a distant oasis together with another passenger. His aide, Sergeant Watson feigns a sprained ankle and does not join Harris. A third man follows after them. Days later, Harris barely manages to return to the crash site. The others are lost.
As the water begins to run out, Stringer<!-- The Englishman, Stinger, belongs to the book, which this article is about. The German, Dorffman, belongs to the movie, for which there is another article; see [The Flight of the Phoenix (1965 film)] -->, a precise, arrogant English [[aeronautical engineer]], proposes a radical solution. He claims they can rebuild a new aircraft from the wreckage of the old [[twin-boom aircraft]], using the undamaged boom and adding skids to take off. They set to work.
At one point, they spot a party of [[nomad]]ic tribesmen. Captain Harris decides to ask them for help, but Sergeant Watson refuses to accompany him. Instead another survivor, a Texan named Loomis, goes with him. The next day, Towns finds their looted bodies, throats cut, and the nomads gone.
Later, Towns finds out that Stringer's job is designing [[Model aircraft|''model'' aircraft]], not real, full-scale ones. Afraid of the effect on morale, he and Moran keep their discovery secret, though they now believe Stringer's plan is doomed. However, they turn out to be wrong. The aircraft is reborn, like the mythical [[Phoenix (mythology)|Phoenix]]. It flies the passengers, strapped to the outside of the fuselage, to an [[oasis]] and civilization.
==Film adaptations== {{Main article|The Flight of the Phoenix (1965 film)|Flight of the Phoenix (2004 film)}} The book was the basis of a 1965 film starring [[James Stewart]], [[Richard Attenborough]], and [[Hardy Krüger]]. The 2004 remake featuring [[Dennis Quaid]] was also based on the novel, although it was re-located to the [[Gobi Desert]] in Asia.
==See also== * [[Coffman engine starter]] * [[Lady Be Good (aircraft)|''Lady Be Good'' (aircraft)]] * [[Tragedy at Kufra]]
